summary.en: A slipper is usually a soft indoor shoe worn for comfort; less commonly, it can mean someone or something that slips.
summary.zh: slipper 通常指柔软舒适的室内拖鞋；较少见的意思是“会滑的人/物”。

definition.en: a soft, comfortable shoe that you wear indoors
definition.zh: 拖鞋；室内便鞋（柔软、舒适，通常在室内穿）

examples.en: I always wear slippers at home in winter.
examples.zh: 冬天我在家总是穿拖鞋。

examples.en: Please take off your shoes and put on these slippers.
examples.zh: 请脱鞋，换上这双拖鞋。

definition.en: a person or thing that slips (moves smoothly, often unintentionally)
definition.zh: 滑倒的人；容易滑动的东西（较少用，偏文学或描述性用法）

examples.en: On the icy steps, he was an easy slipper.
examples.zh: 在结冰的台阶上，他很容易滑倒。

extraExplanation: “slipper”作“室内拖鞋”最常见。英式英语里也常说“a pair of slippers”。在一些文化场景中，进门换拖鞋是一种礼貌与卫生习惯。
注意区分：slipper（室内拖鞋） vs. sandal（凉鞋） vs. flip-flop（人字拖） vs. loafer（乐福鞋，外穿皮鞋类）。

summary.en: Slipperiness means the quality of being slippery, and figuratively it can describe something hard to define or someone evasive/untrustworthy.
summary.zh: Slipperiness 指“湿滑/易滑”的性质；也可比喻概念难以界定，或人说话做事闪躲、不太可信。

definition.en: the quality of being slippery; a surface condition that makes it easy to slide or lose footing
definition.zh: （表面）滑的特性；使人容易打滑或站不稳的状况

examples.en: Be careful—the bathroom floor has a lot of slipperiness after a shower.
examples.zh: 小心——洗完澡后浴室地面很滑。

examples.en: Winter roads can be dangerous because of ice and slipperiness.
examples.zh: 冬天的道路会因为结冰和湿滑而很危险。

definition.en: (figurative) the quality of being hard to control, predict, or deal with
definition.zh: （比喻）难以控制、难以预测或难以应对的性质

examples.en: The slipperiness of the concept makes it difficult to define clearly.
examples.zh: 这个概念很“滑”，因此很难给出清晰的定义。

examples.en: In politics, the slipperiness of language can hide the real meaning.
examples.zh: 在政治中，语言的“滑头”性质可能会掩盖真实含义。

definition.en: (figurative) a tendency to be evasive or untrustworthy; the quality of “slipping away” from responsibility or truth
definition.zh: （比喻）狡猾、闪躲、不可信；容易“溜走”、逃避责任或真相的特质

examples.en: The lawyer criticized the witness’s slipperiness under questioning.
examples.zh: 律师批评证人在盘问时很会闪躲。

examples.en: His slipperiness made coworkers doubt his promises.
examples.zh: 他的不可靠让同事怀疑他的承诺。

extraExplanation: “slipperiness”来自形容词 slippery（滑的）+ 名词后缀 -ness（表示“……的性质/状态”）。既可指真实的“地滑”，也常用于学术写作或评论里，形容概念、语言或人的态度“抓不住、不好界定”。
近义词提示：表示“地滑”常用 slickness（更偏“光滑、打蜡般的滑”）或 slipperiness；表示“难以理解/不清晰”可用 vagueness（含糊）、ambiguity（歧义）；表示“人不可信/会闪躲”可用 evasiveness（闪躲）、shadiness（可疑，口语）。

summary.en: Slippers are soft shoes you wear indoors to feel comfortable and keep your feet warm.
summary.zh: Slippers 指室内穿的柔软舒适的鞋（拖鞋/室内鞋），用于放松或保暖。

definition.en: Soft, comfortable shoes worn indoors, usually without laces.
definition.zh: 拖鞋；室内穿的柔软舒适的鞋，通常没有鞋带。

examples.en: I put on my slippers after I got home.
examples.zh: 我回家后就穿上了拖鞋。

examples.en: These slippers keep my feet warm in winter.
examples.zh: 这双拖鞋在冬天能让我的脚保持温暖。

definition.en: (Plural) A pair of indoor shoes (treated as one item).
definition.zh: （复数形式）一双拖鞋（作为一件物品整体来指）。

examples.en: Where are my slippers? I can’t find them.
examples.zh: 我的拖鞋在哪儿？我找不到了。

examples.en: He bought a new pair of slippers for his dad.
examples.zh: 他给爸爸买了一双新拖鞋。

extraExplanation: “Slippers”通常用复数形式来表示“一双拖鞋”，就像“shoes/jeans/glasses”常用复数一样。
英式英语里有时会用“slippers”指更正式、包脚的室内鞋；美式英语里也常用来泛指各种室内拖鞋。

summary.en: Slippery means easy to slide on or hard to hold, and it can also describe ideas that are hard to define or people who are evasive and untrustworthy.
summary.zh: Slippery 指“容易打滑/不好抓握”，也可比喻“难以界定”，或形容人“滑头、爱推脱、不可靠”。

definition.en: Smooth, wet, or oily so that it is easy to slide or fall on.
definition.zh: （表面）光滑、潮湿或有油，容易打滑的。

examples.en: Be careful—the floor is slippery after the rain.
examples.zh: 小心——下雨后地板很滑。

examples.en: The road gets slippery when it freezes.
examples.zh: 结冰时路面会很滑。

definition.en: Hard to hold, catch, or keep because it slides out of your hands.
definition.zh: （物体）很滑、不好抓握或不易拿稳的。

examples.en: The fish was slippery and kept jumping out of my hands.
examples.zh: 那条鱼很滑，一直从我手里跳走。

definition.en: Difficult to understand, define, or deal with; not clear or fixed.
definition.zh: （概念/问题）难以界定或把握的；不清晰、不固定的。

examples.en: The idea of “success” can be slippery—different people mean different things.
examples.zh: “成功”的概念可能很难界定——不同的人意思不同。

definition.en: Not honest or trustworthy; using tricks to avoid responsibility or give a direct answer.
definition.zh: （人/言行）狡猾的、不可靠的；用话术逃避责任或不正面回答的。

examples.en: He gave a slippery answer that avoided the real question.
examples.zh: 他给了一个滑头的回答，回避了真正的问题。

examples.en: She seems slippery—I wouldn’t trust her promises.
examples.zh: 她看起来很滑头——我不会相信她的承诺。

extraExplanation: “slippery”既可形容真实的“打滑”，也常用作比喻，表示“难以捉摸/难以界定”（slippery concept / slippery definition）。
形容人时带有负面评价，接近“狡猾、会耍滑、爱推脱”，常见搭配有：slippery politician（滑头的政客）、slippery excuse（狡辩的借口）。
常见相关表达：slippery slope（滑坡谬误/一旦开始就会越来越糟的趋势），get slippery（变得很滑）。

summary.en: “Slipping” usually means sliding or falling accidentally; it can also mean leaving quietly, putting something in secretly, or gradually getting worse.
summary.zh: “slipping”通常指不小心滑动或滑倒；也可指悄悄离开、偷偷塞入某物，或状况逐渐变差/下滑。

definition.en: moving, falling, or sliding accidentally because a surface is smooth, wet, or unstable
definition.zh: （因表面光滑、潮湿或不稳而）滑动；打滑；滑倒

examples.en: Be careful—the floor is wet, and people keep slipping.
examples.zh: 小心点——地板是湿的，人们一直在滑倒。

examples.en: My shoes were slipping on the ice.
examples.zh: 我的鞋在冰上一直打滑。

definition.en: leaving or moving away quietly and unnoticed
definition.zh: 悄悄离开；溜走

examples.en: He was slipping out of the meeting to take a call.
examples.zh: 他正悄悄溜出会议去接电话。

examples.en: She noticed him slipping away before the photos.
examples.zh: 她注意到他在拍照前就悄悄走了。

definition.en: putting something somewhere quickly and quietly, often so others won’t notice
definition.zh: （趁人不注意）悄悄放入；塞进

examples.en: She was slipping the note into her pocket.
examples.zh: 她正把纸条悄悄塞进兜里。

examples.en: He kept slipping extra snacks into the bag for the kids.
examples.zh: 他不停地往包里悄悄多塞些零食给孩子们。

definition.en: gradually getting worse, lower, or less successful
definition.zh: 逐渐变差；下滑

examples.en: His grades are slipping this semester.
examples.zh: 他这学期成绩在下滑。

examples.en: The team is slipping in the rankings.
examples.zh: 这支队伍在排名上逐渐下滑。

extraExplanation: “slip”常指不小心的短暂失足或小幅滑动（slipping on ice），也常引申为“悄悄离开/偷偷放入”（slip out / slip into）。而“slide”更偏向“平稳地滑行”，不一定带有“失误/不小心”的感觉。
常见搭配：slipping on (the floor/ice), slipping out of (a room/meeting), slip a note into (a pocket), slipping behind / slipping away。

summary.en: “Slips” can be the verb form meaning “moves/falls by sliding” or “makes a small mistake,” and it can also be the plural noun meaning “small mistakes/accidents” or “paper slips (forms/receipts).”
summary.zh: “Slips”既可作动词（滑动/滑倒；不小心出错），也可作名词复数（小失误/小意外；纸条或单据）。

definition.en: (verb) Third-person singular of “slip”: to slide or move smoothly and quietly, often by accident.
definition.zh: （动词）“slip”的第三人称单数：滑动、悄悄移动，常常是不小心发生的。

examples.en: He slips on the wet floor and nearly falls.
examples.zh: 他在湿地板上滑了一下，差点摔倒。

examples.en: The letter slips out of the envelope.
examples.zh: 信从信封里滑了出来。

definition.en: (verb) To make a small mistake or say/do something unintentionally.
definition.zh: （动词）不小心出错；无意中说错或做错。

examples.en: She sometimes slips when she’s nervous and says the wrong word.
examples.zh: 她紧张时有时会口误，说错词。

examples.en: His name slips my mind at the worst moment.
examples.zh: 最关键的时候我却把他的名字给忘了。

definition.en: (noun, plural) More than one “slip”: a small accident, mistake, or moment of losing balance/attention.
definition.zh: （名词复数）“slip”的复数：小意外、小错误，或一时不稳/分心。

examples.en: Minor slips happen, but we can fix them.
examples.zh: 小失误会发生，但我们可以纠正。

examples.en: There were a few slips in the report, so she edited it again.
examples.zh: 报告里有几处错误，所以她又编辑了一遍。

definition.en: (noun, plural) Pieces of paper (often small) used for notes, forms, or receipts.
definition.zh: （名词复数）纸条/单据（常指小纸片），用于记事、表格或收据等。

examples.en: Please sign the slips and return them tomorrow.
examples.zh: 请在这些单子上签名，明天交回来。

examples.en: He wrote the phone number on little slips of paper.
examples.zh: 他把电话号码写在几张小纸条上。

extraExplanation: “slip”作名词时常见两类意思：①“失误/小差错”（a slip of the tongue 口误）；②“纸条/单据”（pay slip 工资单，packing slip 装箱单）。根据上下文判断最自然。
在口语里，“It slips my mind”表示“我一时想不起来/突然忘了”，语气比“I forgot”更像“临时记不住”。

summary.en: Slipshod describes careless, messy, low-quality work or behavior.
summary.zh: slipshod 用来形容做事马虎草率、敷衍、质量不高。

definition.en: Done in a careless, messy, and not thorough way; showing little attention to quality or detail.
definition.zh: 马虎的；草率的；敷衍的（指做事不认真、质量不高、不够细致）。

examples.en: The report was full of mistakes because of slipshod editing.
examples.zh: 这份报告错误很多，因为编辑得很马虎。

examples.en: Customers complained about the slipshod service at the restaurant.
examples.zh: 顾客抱怨这家餐厅的服务很敷衍。

examples.en: He handed in a slipshod assignment and got a low grade.
examples.zh: 他交了一份草率的作业，得了低分。

definition.en: Careless work or behavior; lack of thoroughness or attention to detail.
definition.zh: 马虎草率的做法；敷衍（指不认真、缺乏细致与严谨）。

examples.en: There’s no room for slipshod in a job where safety matters.
examples.zh: 在重视安全的工作中，容不得半点马虎。

examples.en: The manager criticized the team’s slipshod and asked for a redo.
examples.zh: 经理批评团队做事敷衍，要求重做。

extraExplanation: 词源上与“slip（滑、松脱）”和“shod（穿鞋的）”有关，最早可指“鞋子穿得松松垮垮、拖沓不整”，后来引申为“做事拖沓、马虎、不讲究”。
常见搭配：slipshod work（草率的工作）、slipshod thinking（粗疏的思考）、slipshod manner（敷衍的态度）。语气多为批评、带负面评价。

summary.en: “Slit” means a long, narrow opening (noun) or to make such a cut (verb).
summary.zh: “slit”指“狭长的缝/裂口”（名词），也指“划开形成狭长切口”（动词）。

definition.en: A long, narrow opening or cut, often not wide enough to put something through easily.
definition.zh: 狭长的开口；细长的裂缝（通常很窄，不容易把东西穿过去）。

examples.en: A thin line of light came through a slit in the curtain.
examples.zh: 一缕细光从窗帘的缝隙里透进来。

examples.en: He looked through the slit in the fence.
examples.zh: 他透过篱笆上的一道窄缝往里看。

definition.en: To make a long, narrow cut or opening in something.
definition.zh: 切开；划开（形成狭长的口子）。

examples.en: She slit the envelope open with a knife.
examples.zh: 她用小刀把信封划开。

examples.en: Be careful not to slit the fabric by accident.
examples.zh: 小心别不小心把布料划破。

extraExplanation: 动词不规则变化：slit – slit – slit（现在式/过去式/过去分词都一样）。例如：He slit the bag open. / The bag was slit open.
在日常英语里，slit 常带有“细长、窄而直”的感觉；如果是更一般的“割/切”，也常用 cut。slit 更强调“开出一条缝”。
在文学描写中，slit 常用来写“光的一线”“目光的一线”（a slit of light / a slit-eyed stare），画面感很强。

summary.en: “Slitan” is not a standard English word; it’s likely a misspelling of a similar word.
summary.zh: “slitan”不是标准英语单词；很可能是相近单词的拼写错误。

definition.en: Not a standard English word. It is most likely a misspelling of another word (for example, “slit,” “sultan,” or “slattern,” depending on what you meant).
definition.zh: 不是标准英语单词。很可能是其他单词的拼写错误（例如根据你的意思，可能是“slit”“sultan”或“slattern”等）。

examples.en: I couldn’t find “slitan” in a dictionary—did you mean “slit” (a narrow cut)?
examples.zh: 我在词典里找不到“slitan”——你是想说“slit”（狭长的切口）吗？

examples.en: If you tell me the sentence you saw it in, I can help identify the correct word.
examples.zh: 如果你把看到它的句子发给我，我可以帮你确定正确的词。

extraExplanation:
“slitan”更像是拼写误差。常见的接近词有：
1) slit（名词/动词）：狭长的裂口；切开一条细缝。
2) sultan（名词）：苏丹（伊斯兰国家的君主/统治者）。
3) slattern（名词）：邋遢、不修边幅的人（带批评语气）。

把原句或你想表达的中文意思发来，我可以帮你精准匹配并给出正确发音与用法。

summary.en: “Slitet” isn’t standard English; you probably mean “slit” (a narrow cut/opening; to cut a narrow opening) or “slitted” (having a slit).
summary.zh: “slitet”不是标准英语；你可能想写“slit”（狭缝/切开狭缝）或“slitted”（有开口/开衩的）。

definition.en: Not a standard English word. It is likely a misspelling or a non-English form (often confused with “slit,” “slitted,” or “slightest”).
definition.zh: 不是标准英语单词。很可能是拼写错误或非英语形式（常被误写为“slit / slitted / slightest”等）。

examples.en: I couldn’t find “slitet” in an English dictionary—did you mean “slit” or “slitted”?
examples.zh: 我在英语词典里找不到“slitet”——你是想写“slit”还是“slitted”吗？

examples.en: The paper was slit down the middle.
examples.zh: 纸从中间被割开了一道口子。

definition.en: (Most likely intended) “slit” (noun): a long, narrow cut or opening.
definition.zh: （最可能想表达的）“slit”（名词）：细长的切口或狭缝。

examples.en: There was a slit in the curtain, so light came through.
examples.zh: 窗帘上有一道细缝，所以光透了进来。

examples.en: He looked through the slit in the door.
examples.zh: 他从门缝里往外看。

definition.en: (Most likely intended) “slit” (verb): to cut something with a long, narrow opening.
definition.zh: （最可能想表达的）“slit”（动词）：切开形成一道细长的口子。

examples.en: Be careful not to slit the bag with the knife.
examples.zh: 小心别用刀把袋子划开。

examples.en: The tailor slit the fabric to make room for the zipper.
examples.zh: 裁缝把布料割开，给拉链留出位置。

definition.en: (Related form) “slitted” (adjective): having a slit or slits.
definition.zh: （相关形式）“slitted”（形容词）：有狭缝的；被割开成缝的。

examples.en: She wore a slitted skirt that allowed easier movement.
examples.zh: 她穿了一条开衩裙，走路更方便。

examples.en: The envelope was slitted open.
examples.zh: 信封被划开了。

extraExplanation: “slitet”常见于非英语语境的拼写/词形（例如某些北欧语言里可能出现类似形式），但在英语里不作为常用词条。
如果你是从某段文字/歌词/游戏里看到“slitet”，把原句发我，我可以根据上下文判断它更可能对应哪一个英语词（如 slit / slitted / slightest 等）。

summary.en: Slither means to move by sliding and twisting like a snake, or to move in a sneaky, quiet way; it can also name that kind of movement.
summary.zh: Slither 指像蛇一样蜿蜒滑行，也可指悄悄、鬼祟地移动；还可作名词表示这种滑行动作。

definition.en: to move smoothly along a surface by sliding and twisting from side to side (like a snake)
definition.zh: （像蛇一样）贴着地面蜿蜒滑行

examples.en: The snake slithered into the grass.
examples.zh: 那条蛇蜿蜒滑进了草丛里。

examples.en: I saw a lizard slither across the warm rock.
examples.zh: 我看到一只蜥蜴从温热的岩石上滑过去。

definition.en: to move quietly and smoothly in a way that feels sneaky or hard to notice
definition.zh: （悄悄地）溜走；不动声色地移动（常带“鬼鬼祟祟”的感觉）

examples.en: He slithered out of the room before anyone could stop him.
examples.zh: 他趁没人拦得住，悄悄溜出了房间。

examples.en: The rumor slithered through the office in just one afternoon.
examples.zh: 这个谣言一个下午就在办公室里悄悄传开了。

definition.en: a smooth, sliding movement like that of a snake
definition.zh: 蛇行般的滑动；蜿蜒的滑行

examples.en: With one quick slither, it disappeared under the leaves.
examples.zh: 它一下子蜿蜒一滑，就钻到叶子下面不见了。

extraExplanation: “slither”常带有画面感：身体贴着地面、左右扭动、带点“滑溜溜”的感觉。用于人时，通常含贬义或不舒服的语气，暗示此人行事鬼祟、令人不信任。
写作中常把“slither”用作拟人或比喻：比如“fear slithered into my mind（恐惧悄悄爬进我的脑海）”，强调一种慢慢渗入、让人不安的感觉。

summary.en: “Slithered” is the past tense of “slither,” meaning moved smoothly and twistily like a snake; it can also mean sneaked away or slid along a surface.
summary.zh: “Slithered”是“slither”的过去式，表示像蛇一样扭动着平滑移动；也可引申为偷偷溜走，或沿着表面滑动。

definition.en: moved smoothly along a surface, often in a twisting way like a snake (past tense of “slither”).
definition.zh: （slither 的过去式）像蛇一样扭动着平滑地向前移动。

examples.en: The snake slithered across the road and disappeared into the grass.
examples.zh: 那条蛇扭动着爬过马路，消失在草丛里。

examples.en: A lizard slithered under the warm rock to hide.
examples.zh: 一只蜥蜴钻到温热的石头下面躲起来。

definition.en: moved quietly or secretly in a way that suggests sneaking or being unpleasant (figurative use).
definition.zh: （比喻）鬼鬼祟祟地移动；给人“不光彩、令人不快”的潜行感。

examples.en: He slithered out of the room before anyone could ask questions.
examples.zh: 还没人来得及问问题，他就悄悄溜出了房间。

examples.en: Rumors slithered through the school and made everyone nervous.
examples.zh: 谣言在学校里悄悄传开，让大家都很紧张。

definition.en: slid or moved in an uncontrolled way, often because a surface was wet, smooth, or steep (less common).
definition.zh: （较少见）打滑、滑动（常因表面湿滑、光滑或陡峭而失控）。

examples.en: The box slithered down the icy steps.
examples.zh: 箱子从结冰的台阶上滑了下去。

extraExplanation: “slither”常带有强烈的画面感：身体贴地、左右扭动、连续流动的移动方式，所以很常用来写蛇、鳗鱼、蜥蜴等。
比喻用法里，“slither”往往带负面语气，暗示偷偷摸摸、令人不舒服或不诚实的感觉；写人时要注意语气是否合适。
常见搭配：slither away（溜走）、slither out of（溜出/设法逃避）、slither into（悄悄进入）。

summary.en: “Slithering” describes smooth, twisting movement like a snake; it can also mean sliding along or down a surface.
summary.zh: “slithering”指像蛇一样平滑扭动地移动，也可指沿着表面滑行或向下滑落。

definition.en: Moving smoothly and quietly across a surface in a twisting, snake-like way.
definition.zh: 以蛇一样扭动、贴地而平滑安静地移动。

examples.en: A snake was slithering through the grass.
examples.zh: 一条蛇正从草丛中蜿蜒爬行。

examples.en: We saw something dark slithering under the rocks.
examples.zh: 我们看到有个黑色的东西在岩石下蜿蜒穿过。

definition.en: The present participle of “slither”: to move in a smooth, sliding way, often like a snake.
definition.zh: “slither”的现在分词：以平滑的方式滑行或蜿蜒前进，常像蛇一样。

examples.en: The lizard is slithering away to hide.
examples.zh: 蜥蜴正蜿蜒溜走去躲起来。

examples.en: Mud was slithering down the hill after the heavy rain.
examples.zh: 大雨过后，泥浆从山坡上滑下。

extraExplanation: “slither”常用来描写蛇、蜥蜴等爬行动物的移动方式，也可用来形容液体/泥浆等“滑动、缓慢下滑”。
在文学或叙述中，“slithering”有时带一点阴森、偷偷摸摸的氛围，因为它强调“无声、贴地、蜿蜒”的动作感。

summary.en: “Slits” usually means narrow, long openings or cuts; it can also describe making such cuts.
summary.zh: “slits”通常指狭长的缝隙/切口；也可表示“划开狭长切口”的动作形式。

definition.en: Narrow openings or cuts, often long and thin.
definition.zh: 狭长的开口或切口（常又长又窄）。

examples.en: Sunlight came through the slits in the curtains.
examples.zh: 阳光从窗帘的缝隙里透进来。

examples.en: There are slits in the envelope so it can be opened easily.
examples.zh: 信封上有便于打开的切口。

definition.en: The plural form of “slit”; it can also be the third-person singular present of the verb “slit” (to make a long, narrow cut).
definition.zh: “slit”的复数；也可以是动词“slit”的第三人称单数现在时（指划开一道狭长的切口）。

examples.en: The cat slits its eyes in bright light.
examples.zh: 光线很强时，猫会把眼睛眯成一条缝。

examples.en: The machine slits the paper into thin strips.
examples.zh: 这台机器把纸裁成细条。

extraExplanation: “slit”常见搭配：slits in the curtains（窗帘的缝）、a slit skirt/dress（开衩裙/连衣裙）、slit the envelope open（把信封划开）。
注意区分：cut 是泛指“切/割”，slit 更强调“又长又窄的一道口子”。
在描写中（尤其是文学/电影镜头语言里），“a slit of light”（一线光）很常用，画面感强。

summary.en: Sliver means a very thin, small piece of something, or a very small amount (like a sliver of hope). It can also be a verb meaning to split into thin pieces.
summary.zh: Sliver 指“细长薄片”，也可指“极少量”（如一丝希望）。作动词可表示“裂成细片”。

definition.en: A very small, thin piece cut or broken off from something.
definition.zh: （从某物上切下或断下的）细长小片；薄片

examples.en: I got a sliver of glass in my finger.
examples.zh: 我手指里扎进了一小片玻璃。

examples.en: He shaved off a sliver of wood with a knife.
examples.zh: 他用刀削下一小片木头。

definition.en: A very small amount of something, especially hope, time, or light.
definition.zh: （希望、时间、光等的）一丝；一点点

examples.en: There’s still a sliver of hope.
examples.zh: 仍然还有一丝希望。

examples.en: A sliver of moonlight came through the curtains.
examples.zh: 一缕月光透过窗帘照进来。

definition.en: To split into thin pieces or fragments.
definition.zh: 裂成细片；碎成薄片

examples.en: The ice began to sliver along the edges.
examples.zh: 冰开始在边缘裂成细片。

definition.en: Very thin and narrow.
definition.zh: 细长的；狭窄的

examples.en: They walked along a sliver path between the fields.
examples.zh: 他们走在田地之间一条狭窄的小路上。

extraExplanation: “sliver”常和“splinter”一起比较：splinter 更常指扎进皮肤的“木刺/碎片”（尤其是木头）；sliver 更强调“很薄、很细的一片”，材质可以是玻璃、金属、木头等。
常见搭配：a sliver of hope/time/light（“一丝希望/一点时间/一缕光”），强调“少到几乎没有”。
拼写注意：sliver（细片）≠ silver（银；银色）。两者读音不同，写作时容易混淆。

summary.en: “slm” is a chat abbreviation meaning “hi/hello” (from salaam/selam), or it can be initials “SLM” whose meaning depends on context.
summary.zh: “slm”常见于聊天中，表示“嗨/你好”（源自 salaam/selam）；也可能只是字母缩写“SLM”，具体含义看上下文。

definition.en: (Internet/texting) A short form used mainly by Arabic/Turkish/Persian speakers to mean “hi/hello,” from greetings like salaam/selam (“peace”).
definition.zh: （网络/短信）主要由阿拉伯语/土耳其语/波斯语使用者用的缩写，意思是“嗨/你好”，源自 salaam/selam（本义与“平安/和平”有关）的问候语。

examples.en: slm, how are you?
examples.zh: slm，你好吗？

examples.en: He replied “slm” and then started chatting.
examples.zh: 他回了句“slm”，然后开始聊天。

examples.en: In English-only chats, many people won’t recognize “slm,” so you can just say “hi.”
examples.zh: 在纯英语聊天里，很多人不认识“slm”，你直接说“hi”就行。

definition.en: A written abbreviation for the letters “SLM,” used as initials for different phrases or organization names (meaning depends on context).
definition.zh: 字母缩写“SLM”（具体含义取决于上下文），可作为不同词组或机构名称的首字母缩写。

examples.en: What does SLM stand for in this document?
examples.zh: 这份文件里的 SLM 是什么的缩写？

examples.en: SLM can mean different things in different fields.
examples.zh: SLM 在不同领域可能代表不同含义。

extraExplanation: “slm”在很多聊天语境里对应的是阿拉伯语“سلام”（salaam，意为平安/和平）或土耳其语“selam”（你好/问候）。因此它更像是一种跨语言的网络写法，而不是标准英语单词。
正式英文写作或不熟悉该缩写的人群中，建议直接用“hi / hello”，避免对方看不懂。

summary.en: “Slobber” means to drool (saliva running from the mouth), the drool itself, or—figuratively—to admire or gush over something in an overexcited way.
summary.zh: “slobber”指流口水、口水本身，也可比喻对某人或某物过度热切地迷恋或吹捧。

definition.en: To let saliva run from the mouth; to drool.
definition.zh: （口水）从嘴里流出来；流口水。

examples.en: The dog slobbered all over my hand when I offered a treat.
examples.zh: 我给它零食时，那只狗把口水都流到我手上了。

examples.en: The baby was slobbering while chewing on a toy.
examples.zh: 宝宝咬着玩具时一直流口水。

definition.en: Saliva or drool, especially in a messy way.
definition.zh: （尤指很邋遢的）口水，涎水。

examples.en: There was slobber on the pillow when the puppy woke up.
examples.zh: 小狗醒来时，枕头上有口水。

examples.en: Wipe that slobber off your chin.
examples.zh: 把你下巴上的口水擦掉。

definition.en: To speak or show feelings in an overly excited, admiring, or eager way (often a bit negative).
definition.zh: （常含贬义）过分兴奋地夸赞/仰慕；热切到有点失态地表达。

examples.en: Some fans slobber over every photo the celebrity posts.
examples.zh: 有些粉丝对明星发的每张照片都过度吹捧。

examples.en: He was slobbering about the new sports car like it was perfect.
examples.zh: 他把那辆新跑车夸得过头，好像完美无缺。

extraExplanation: “slobber”常用来形容动物或婴儿的流口水，语感偏“湿、黏、脏乱”。如果只是中性地说“流口水”，也可以用更常见的“drool”。
比喻义（对某人/某物“slobber over”）带有轻微讽刺：像“口水直流”一样夸张地崇拜或渴望。常见搭配：slobber all over + 物（弄得到处都是口水）；slobber over + 人/物（过度迷恋/夸赞）。

summary.en: Slog means to work or move with great effort for a long time; it can also mean a tiring task or journey.
summary.zh: slog 指长时间费力地工作或艰难前进；也可指一段辛苦的工作或行程。

definition.en: to work very hard at something for a long time, especially when it is tiring or boring
definition.zh: （尤指疲惫或枯燥时）长时间吃力地工作；苦干

examples.en: I’ve been slogging all week to finish this report.
examples.zh: 我整个星期都在苦干，想把这份报告做完。

examples.en: She slogged away at her homework until midnight.
examples.zh: 她埋头做作业一直做到半夜。

examples.en: They’re slogging through a mountain of emails.
examples.zh: 他们正在硬着头皮处理一大堆邮件。

definition.en: to walk or move with difficulty, usually because you are tired, in bad weather, or in a difficult place
definition.zh: （因疲劳、恶劣天气或路难走而）艰难地走；吃力地前进

examples.en: We slogged through the snow to get home.
examples.zh: 我们在雪地里艰难跋涉才到家。

examples.en: He slogged up the hill with a heavy backpack.
examples.zh: 他背着沉重的背包吃力地爬上山坡。

definition.en: a long, tiring period of hard work or a difficult journey
definition.zh: 艰苦而漫长的工作（或行程）；苦差事

examples.en: Writing the thesis was a real slog.
examples.zh: 写论文真是一场苦战。

examples.en: The last few miles were a slog.
examples.zh: 最后几英里走得特别艰难。

extraExplanation: “slog”在口语里很常见，常与介词/副词连用：slog through（艰难完成、硬着头皮做完），slog away（持续苦干）。语气强调“很累但还在坚持”。

summary.en: A slogan is a short, memorable phrase that represents an idea, brand, or cause.
summary.zh: slogan 指表达理念、品牌或诉求的简短好记的“口号/宣传语”。

definition.en: A short, memorable phrase used in advertising, politics, or social movements to express an idea and persuade people.
definition.zh: （广告、政治或社会运动中）用于表达观点并吸引/说服大众的简短、易记的口号。

examples.en: The company’s new slogan is “Built to last.”
examples.zh: 这家公司新的宣传口号是“经久耐用”。

examples.en: Protesters chanted slogans calling for change.
examples.zh: 抗议者高喊要求改变的口号。

examples.en: A good slogan is simple, clear, and easy to remember.
examples.zh: 好的口号通常简单、清晰、容易记。

definition.en: (Less common) A distinctive motto or catchphrase associated with a group, school, or person.
definition.zh: （较少见）与某个团体、学校或个人相关的格言/标语式短句。

examples.en: The club adopted a slogan that emphasized teamwork.
examples.zh: 这个社团采用了一句强调团队合作的口号。

extraExplanation: “slogan”常见于营销与政治语境：商业里更偏“品牌宣传语/广告语”，政治与社会运动里更偏“标语/口号”。中文里可按场景译为“口号、标语、宣传语”。
词源上它来自盖尔语（苏格兰盖尔语等）中表示“战斗呼喊/部族号令”的词，后来引申为现代的广告或政治口号。

summary.en: Sloganize means to create slogans or to turn an idea into a catchy slogan, sometimes oversimplifying it.
summary.zh: sloganize 指创作口号，或把观点“口号化”成顺口的短句，有时暗含过度简化之意。

definition.en: to create slogans for something (a product, campaign, idea)
definition.zh: 为某事创作/设计口号（用于产品、活动、理念等）

examples.en: The agency was hired to sloganize the new public health campaign.
examples.zh: 这家广告公司被雇来为新的公共卫生宣传活动设计口号。

examples.en: They want to sloganize their brand so customers remember it easily.
examples.zh: 他们想用口号化的方式打造品牌，让顾客更容易记住。

definition.en: to express an idea as a short, catchy slogan (often simplifying it)
definition.zh: 把观点用简短上口的口号表达（常带有简化之意）

examples.en: It’s hard to sloganize a complex policy without losing important details.
examples.zh: 复杂政策很难口号化表达而不丢失重要细节。

examples.en: The debate felt sloganized, with people repeating catchy lines instead of reasoning.
examples.zh: 这场辩论感觉被“口号化”了，人们重复顺口的话而不是讲道理。

extraExplanation: “sloganize”由“slogan（口号）+ -ize（使……化）”构成，常见于营销、广告、政治传播语境。它有时带一点批评意味，暗示把复杂问题过度简化成口号。
拼写也可见到较少用的变体“sloganise”（英式拼写）。

summary.en: “Slop” means messy watery food or liquid, and informally it can mean low-quality content; as a verb it means to spill/splash or to move through mud/liquid.
summary.zh: “slop”指难吃的稀糊食物/脏乱液体；口语中也指粗制滥造的内容；作动词可指把液体泼洒得很乱或在泥水中蹚行。

definition.en: Thin, watery, or messy liquid food or drink (often considered unpleasant), such as watery soup or animal feed.
definition.zh: （常带贬义）稀薄、糊状或很脏乱的液体食物/饮料，如寡汤或喂牲畜的稀食。

examples.en: The soup was just slop—thin and tasteless.
examples.zh: 这汤简直像糊弄人的稀汤——又稀又没味。

examples.en: They fed the pigs warm slop in a big bucket.
examples.zh: 他们用大桶给猪喂温热的稀食。

definition.en: Careless or low-quality work, writing, or content; something made with little effort (informal).
definition.zh: （非正式）粗制滥造的作品/文字/内容；敷衍出来的东西。

examples.en: Don’t turn in slop—take time to edit your essay.
examples.zh: 别交这种粗糙的东西——花点时间把作文改一改。

examples.en: The site is full of clickbait slop.
examples.zh: 这个网站全是标题党垃圾内容。

definition.en: To spill, splash, or pour a liquid carelessly, making a mess.
definition.zh: （液体）泼洒、溅出；不小心倒得到处都是。

examples.en: Try not to slop coffee on the table.
examples.zh: 尽量别把咖啡洒到桌子上。

examples.en: He slopped water from the bucket onto the floor.
examples.zh: 他把桶里的水洒得地上一片。

definition.en: To move around in a wet, muddy, or messy way; to wade through liquid or mud.
definition.zh: 在湿泥或脏乱的液体中走动；蹚过去。

examples.en: We slopped through the mud after the storm.
examples.zh: 暴风雨后我们在泥里蹚着走。

extraExplanation: “slop”常带强烈的负面评价：形容食物时有“稀、糊、难吃”的感觉；形容内容/作品时，表示“低质、敷衍”。
在网络语境中，你可能会看到“AI slop（AI垃圾内容）”这类说法，用来批评大量生成但质量不高、重复、缺乏用心的内容。

summary.en: Slope means an inclined surface (like a hillside) or the steepness/angle of a line or surface; as a verb, it means to slant or rise/fall gradually.
summary.zh: slope 指“斜坡/坡地”，也指“坡度、斜率”；作动词表示“倾斜”或“逐渐上升/下降”。

definition.en: A surface of land that goes up or down (a hillside or incline).
definition.zh: 斜坡；坡地（地面向上或向下倾斜的地方）。

examples.en: The children rolled down the grassy slope.
examples.zh: 孩子们从长满草的斜坡上滚下来。

examples.en: Be careful on the icy slope near the entrance.
examples.zh: 入口附近的冰斜坡要小心。

definition.en: The steepness or angle of a line or surface; in math, how fast something rises or falls as you move to the right.
definition.zh: （线或面的）斜率、坡度；（数学）表示向右移动时上升或下降的快慢。

examples.en: This road has a steep slope, so trucks drive slowly.
examples.zh: 这条路坡度很陡，所以卡车开得很慢。

examples.en: The line has a positive slope, so it goes up from left to right.
examples.zh: 这条直线的斜率为正，所以从左到右是上升的。

definition.en: To move in a way that is not straight—slant or lean; to go gradually up or down.
definition.zh: 倾斜；（逐渐）上升或下降。

examples.en: The path slopes gently down toward the river.
examples.zh: 小路缓缓向下倾斜通向河边。

examples.en: The roof slopes to let rainwater run off.
examples.zh: 屋顶做成斜的，让雨水流走。

extraExplanation: 在数学里，slope 通常指直线的“斜率”，常用公式是 slope = (y2 − y1) / (x2 − x1)，也写作 Δy/Δx。正斜率表示从左到右上升，负斜率表示从左到右下降。
在日常英语中，slope 常用于描述“地形/道路的坡”和“屋顶的倾斜”。表示“很陡”常搭配 steep（a steep slope）；表示“缓和”常搭配 gentle（a gentle slope）。

summary.en: “Slopes” can mean angled surfaces/areas (plural noun), the steepness of a line in math (plural noun), or the verb form meaning “goes at an angle” (he/she/it slopes).
summary.zh: “slopes”可以指多个斜坡/斜面（名词复数）、数学中的多条斜率（名词复数），也可以是动词“slope”的第三人称单数，表示“（路等）倾斜/逐渐上升或下降”。

definition.en: A slanted surface or the side of something that goes up or down at an angle.
definition.zh: 倾斜的表面；斜坡（向上或向下的斜面）。

examples.en: Be careful on the icy slope.
examples.zh: 在结冰的斜坡上要小心。

examples.en: The house is built on a steep slope.
examples.zh: 这栋房子建在很陡的坡上。

definition.en: In math, the steepness of a line on a graph (how much it rises or falls as you move right).
definition.zh: （数学）斜率：图像中直线的陡峭程度（向右移动时上升或下降的快慢）。

examples.en: The line has a positive slope, so it goes upward from left to right.
examples.zh: 这条直线的斜率为正，所以从左到右是向上的。

examples.en: We calculated the slope using two points.
examples.zh: 我们用两个点来计算斜率。

definition.en: Third-person singular form of “slope”: to be at an angle; to go up or down gradually.
definition.zh: “slope”的第三人称单数：倾斜；逐渐上升或下降。

examples.en: The road slopes down toward the river.
examples.zh: 这条路向河边逐渐下坡。

examples.en: The roof slopes to let rainwater run off.
examples.zh: 屋顶做成斜的，便于雨水流下。

extraExplanation: “slope”在日常英语里常指自然地形或路面的“坡”，在滑雪语境中也常见（ski slope＝滑雪道）。
数学里常用表达：slope = rise/run（纵向变化/横向变化）。常见搭配：steep slope（陡坡）、gentle slope（缓坡）、slippery slope（危险的逐步恶化趋势，常作比喻）。

summary.en: Sloping means angled or gradually going up/down, describing surfaces, paths, or trends.
summary.zh: Sloping 指“有坡度的/倾斜的”，也可指趋势或曲线逐渐上升或下降。

definition.en: Having a surface or line that goes up or down at an angle (not level).
definition.zh: 倾斜的；有坡度的（不水平的）。

examples.en: The house has a sloping roof to let rain and snow slide off.
examples.zh: 这栋房子有一个倾斜的屋顶，方便雨雪滑落。

examples.en: Be careful on the sloping path after it rains.
examples.zh: 下雨后在倾斜的小路上要小心。

definition.en: Moving gradually in a particular direction (often downward), especially in a graph or trend.
definition.zh: （趋势/曲线）逐渐朝某个方向变化的（常指下降）。

examples.en: The line on the graph is sloping downward.
examples.zh: 图表上的那条线正在向下倾斜。

examples.en: Sales are sloping gently over the winter months.
examples.zh: 冬季几个月里销量在缓慢下降。

extraExplanation: “sloping”来自动词“slope”（倾斜）。日常最常见的搭配有：sloping roof（斜屋顶）、sloping hill（斜坡/山坡）、sloping shoulders（溜肩/肩膀下垂，描述体态）。在写作里常用来营造地形画面感，比如“a sloping hillside”。

summary.en: “Sloppy” means messy or not done carefully; it can also describe something wet and mushy.
summary.zh: “sloppy”表示“邋遢/凌乱；粗心不严谨”，也可形容“湿软稀烂的质地”。

definition.en: Messy or untidy; not neat or careful in appearance or work.
definition.zh: 邋遢的；凌乱的；（做事）不细致的、不严谨的。

examples.en: His handwriting is sloppy and hard to read.
examples.zh: 他的字很潦草，很难读。

examples.en: The room looked sloppy after the party.
examples.zh: 派对过后房间显得很凌乱。

examples.en: Be careful—sloppy work can cause mistakes.
examples.zh: 要小心——粗心的工作会造成错误。

definition.en: Careless or lacking precision; not done in a controlled or exact way.
definition.zh: 粗心的；不精确的；不够严密的（常指思考、表达或论证）。

examples.en: That’s a sloppy argument with no clear evidence.
examples.zh: 那是个不严谨的论证，没有明确证据。

examples.en: The report is full of sloppy wording.
examples.zh: 这份报告措辞很不严谨。

definition.en: Very wet, soft, or loose in texture; watery and unpleasantly mushy.
definition.zh: 湿软的；稀烂的；（质地）松散黏糊的。

examples.en: The fries got sloppy in the bag.
examples.zh: 薯条在袋子里捂得软塌塌的。

examples.en: The ground was sloppy after the rain.
examples.zh: 雨后地面泥泞湿软。

extraExplanation: “sloppy”常带负面评价：既可以形容外表/环境的“凌乱”，也很常用来批评工作、写作、思考“不严谨、粗糙”。
常见搭配：sloppy handwriting（潦草字迹）、sloppy work（粗糙/不认真工作）、sloppy argument（不严谨的论证）、sloppy seconds（口语：别人挑剩下的/前任的对象；较敏感，使用需谨慎）。

summary.en: “Slopus” is not a standard English word; it’s likely a typo or a coined name.
summary.zh: “slopus”不是标准英语词；多半是拼写错误或自造名称。

definition.en: Not a standard English word. It is most likely a misspelling or a made-up word (for a username, brand name, or character name).
definition.zh: 不是标准英语单词。更可能是拼写错误，或是人为造的词（例如用户名、品牌名、角色名）。

examples.en: “Slopus” doesn’t appear in major English dictionaries—did you mean “sloppy”?
examples.zh: “slopus”在主要英语词典里查不到——你是不是想写“sloppy（邋遢的/马虎的）”？

examples.en: They named the cartoon character Slopus to sound silly and playful.
examples.zh: 他们把动画角色取名为Slopus，让它听起来更滑稽、可爱。

extraExplanation:
“slopus”可能想表达的常见近似拼写：
- sloppy /ˈslɑpi/（邋遢的；马虎的）
- sloppiness（邋遢；草率）
- slope（斜坡；倾斜）
如果你能提供一句包含“slopus”的原句或截图，我可以更准确判断它的意思。
发音我按英语常见拼读习惯给出 /ˈsloʊpəs/ 作为“可能的读法”，但如果它来自游戏/人名/品牌，读音可能由作者自定。

summary.en: “Slosh” describes liquid moving or splashing around noisily, and it can also mean walking through water or mud with wet sounds.
summary.zh: “slosh”常指液体在容器里哗啦晃动/溅起，也可指在水或泥里蹚着走发出湿重声。

definition.en: (Of a liquid) to move around noisily inside a container, often because it is not full.
definition.zh: （液体）在容器里晃动并发出哗啦声，常因容器未装满而产生。

examples.en: Water sloshed in the bucket as she walked.
examples.zh: 她走路时，桶里的水哗啦哗啦地晃动。

examples.en: Don’t fill the cup too high, or it will slosh out.
examples.zh: 杯子别倒太满，不然会晃出来。

definition.en: To cause liquid to splash or move around noisily by shaking or moving the container.
definition.zh: 使（液体）因晃动容器而溅起或哗啦作响。

examples.en: He sloshed the coffee as he hurried down the hall.
examples.zh: 他匆忙穿过走廊时把咖啡晃得直溅。

examples.en: Try not to slosh the paint onto the floor.
examples.zh: 尽量别把油漆晃到地板上。

definition.en: (Informal) To walk through water or mud with heavy, wet sounds.
definition.zh: （非正式）在水里或泥里蹚着走，发出湿重的声音。

examples.en: We sloshed through puddles after the storm.
examples.zh: 暴风雨后我们蹚着水坑走。

examples.en: She sloshed across the muddy field in rubber boots.
examples.zh: 她穿着雨靴蹚过泥泞的田地。

definition.en: The sound or movement of liquid splashing around.
definition.zh: 液体晃动或溅起的声音/动作。

examples.en: I heard the slosh of waves against the boat.
examples.zh: 我听到海浪拍打船身的哗啦声。

examples.en: With every step, there was a slosh in his soaked shoes.
examples.zh: 他每走一步，湿透的鞋里就传来哗啦的响声。

extraExplanation: “slosh”是拟声词，模仿液体在容器里晃动、溅起时的声音；因此它常和“bucket/cup/waves/puddles”等词搭配。
常见搭配：slosh around（在里面晃来晃去）、sloshing sound（哗啦声）、slosh out/over（晃出来/溅出来）、sloshed（口语：喝醉的）。

summary.en: Slot means a narrow opening, a scheduled time/place in a plan, or a fitting position; as a verb, it means to insert or schedule into a place/time.
summary.zh: Slot 指狭槽/开口、日程中的时间段或系统中的插槽；作动词表示插入或安排进某个位置/时间。

definition.en: A narrow opening or gap in something (often long and thin) where you can insert something.
definition.zh: （通常又长又窄的）缝隙；狭槽；可插入东西的开口。

examples.en: Put the coin into the slot and press the button.
examples.zh: 把硬币投进投币口，然后按按钮。

examples.en: There’s a mail slot in the door.
examples.zh: 门上有一个投信口。

definition.en: A scheduled time or place in a plan (a space in a timetable or program).
definition.zh: （日程/计划中的）时间段；安排位置；名额。

examples.en: Can we find a 30-minute slot for a meeting tomorrow?
examples.zh: 我们明天能找一个30分钟的会议时段吗？

examples.en: She got a slot on the evening news.
examples.zh: 她在晚间新闻里获得了一个出镜/播出位置。

definition.en: A place or position for something to fit into, especially in a machine or system.
definition.zh: （机器/系统中）插槽；卡槽；安装位。

examples.en: This laptop has two memory slots.
examples.zh: 这台笔记本电脑有两个内存插槽。

definition.en: To fit something into a particular place or time; to insert or schedule.
definition.zh: 把……插入/放入；把……安排进（某个时间段/位置）。

examples.en: They slotted the new topic into the lesson plan.
examples.zh: 他们把新主题安排进了课程计划里。

examples.en: Slot the card into the reader.
examples.zh: 把卡插入读卡器。

extraExplanation: “slot”在英式与美式英语中都很常用。生活里常见搭配包括：coin slot（投币口）、time slot（时间段）、parking slot/space（停车位，口语更常说 space）、slot machine（老虎机）。
动词用法里常见结构是 slot A into B（把A塞进/安排进B）或 slot into（顺利进入某个位置/角色），例如：He slotted into the team easily（他很快融入团队并找到自己的位置）。

summary.en: Sloth means a slow rainforest animal, or laziness/lack of effort.
summary.zh: Sloth 可指动作缓慢的雨林动物“树懒”，也可指“懒惰/怠惰”。

definition.en: A slow-moving tropical mammal that lives in trees, known for hanging upside down and moving very slowly.
definition.zh: 树懒：一种生活在热带雨林树上的哺乳动物，以动作非常缓慢、常倒挂在树上而闻名。

examples.en: We saw a sloth hanging from a branch in the rainforest.
examples.zh: 我们在雨林里看到一只树懒倒挂在树枝上。

examples.en: A sloth can spend most of its life in the trees.
examples.zh: 树懒一生大部分时间都待在树上。

definition.en: Laziness or a lack of energy or effort, especially when you should be active.
definition.zh: 懒惰；怠惰：指缺乏精力或努力，尤其在本该积极行动时。

examples.en: He blamed his sloth for not finishing the project on time.
examples.zh: 他把没能按时完成项目归咎于自己的懒惰。

examples.en: Regular exercise can help you fight sloth in the afternoon.
examples.zh: 规律运动能帮助你对抗下午的倦怠与懒散。

extraExplanation: “Sloth”既指动物“树懒”，也指“懒惰”。在西方文化里，sloth 还是基督教传统中“七宗罪”（Seven Deadly Sins）之一，常用来指精神上的懒散、逃避应尽责任。
常见搭配：animal sloth（树懒这种动物）；sloth and procrastination（懒惰与拖延）；shake off your sloth（摆脱懒散）。

summary.en: Slothful means lazy and unwilling to make effort, or moving/progressing very slowly.
summary.zh: Slothful 指懒惰、缺乏干劲，也可指行动或进展迟缓、拖沓。

definition.en: Lazy and slow to make an effort; not willing to work or act with energy.
definition.zh: 懒惰的；怠惰的；做事慢吞吞、不愿意费力的。

examples.en: He became slothful and stopped exercising regularly.
examples.zh: 他变得很懒散，不再规律锻炼了。

examples.en: A slothful attitude at work can hurt your team.
examples.zh: 工作中怠惰的态度会拖累团队。

definition.en: Showing a calm, sluggish pace (often describing movement or progress).
definition.zh: （常形容行动或进展）迟缓的，缓慢的。

examples.en: The project made slothful progress during the holidays.
examples.zh: 假期期间项目进展缓慢。

examples.en: After the heavy meal, we walked home at a slothful pace.
examples.zh: 吃完那顿大餐后，我们慢吞吞地走回家。

extraExplanation: “slothful”来自“sloth（懒惰）”，在传统文化里“sloth（懒惰/怠惰）”也常被当作一种不良品性来批评（如“七宗罪”中的懒惰）。因此它比普通的“lazy”更带一点道德评判或书面语色彩。
用法提示：形容人时常指“缺乏主动性、懒得努力”；形容事情/进展时多指“缓慢、拖沓”。日常口语里更常说“lazy / sluggish / unmotivated”。

summary.en: Slots are narrow openings or available spaces/times in a schedule; the verb means to fit or schedule something into a place or time.
summary.zh: slots 可指“狭长的缝/插槽”，也可指“时间空档/名额”；作动词表示“把……安排进去/插入槽内”。

definition.en: a narrow opening or hole, often long and thin, that something can fit into
definition.zh: （狭长的）缝隙；插孔；槽口（东西可以插入的开口）

examples.en: Put the card into the slot on the machine.
examples.zh: 把卡插进机器上的插槽里。

examples.en: There is a slot in the door for letters.
examples.zh: 门上有一个投信口。

definition.en: an available time or position in a schedule or system
definition.zh: （时间表或安排中的）空档；时段；名额

examples.en: I booked a 10:30 time slot for my appointment.
examples.zh: 我预约了10:30的时间段。

examples.en: There are only two slots left in the class.
examples.zh: 这门课只剩两个名额了。

definition.en: a place, role, or position where someone or something fits in an organization or plan
definition.zh: （组织或计划中的）位置；岗位；角色

examples.en: She found her slot in the company after a few months.
examples.zh: 几个月后，她在公司里找到了适合自己的位置。

definition.en: to put or fit something into a particular place or time in a plan (often: slot into / slot in)
definition.zh: 把……安排进（计划/时间表）；把……插入/放入（槽内）（常用：slot into / slot in）

examples.en: We can slot you in at 3 p.m.
examples.zh: 我们可以把你安排在下午3点。

examples.en: The new topic slots neatly into the lesson plan.
examples.zh: 新话题很顺利地融入了课程计划。

extraExplanation: “slots”常见为复数，尤其在谈“时间段（time slots）/名额（available slots）”时很自然。
“slot machine”指“老虎机”，在美国文化里常见于赌场或部分娱乐场所；口语中也可能简称为“slots”（例如：play slots=玩老虎机）。

summary.en: “Slotted” most often means “having a slot (a narrow opening/groove).” It can also be the past form of “slot,” meaning “to fit or schedule into a space or time.”
summary.zh: “slotted”通常表示“带槽/开有狭长孔的”。也可作动词slot的过去式/过去分词，表示“把……插入/放入空位”或“把……安排进时间段/名额”。

definition.en: Having a narrow opening, groove, or hole (a slot) cut into it, usually to allow something to fit, slide, or be inserted.
definition.zh: 带槽的；开有狭长孔/凹槽的（通常用于插入、滑入或固定某物）。

examples.en: Use a slotted screwdriver to turn this screw.
examples.zh: 用一字（带槽）螺丝刀来拧这颗螺丝。

examples.en: A slotted spoon lets the water drain away when you lift the noodles.
examples.zh: 漏勺（带孔/带槽的勺子）把面条捞起时能让水流走。

examples.en: The shelf has slotted rails, so you can adjust the height.
examples.zh: 这个架子有带槽的导轨，所以你可以调节高度。

definition.en: Past tense/past participle of “slot”: to place, fit, or schedule something into an available space or time.
definition.zh: “slot”的过去式/过去分词：把某物放入（空位/位置）或把某事安排进（时间段）。

examples.en: They slotted the new hire into the team quickly.
examples.zh: 他们很快把新员工安排进团队。

examples.en: I was slotted for the 10:30 appointment.
examples.zh: 我被安排在10:30的预约时段。

examples.en: The card is slotted into the reader.
examples.zh: 卡片被插入读卡器。

extraExplanation: “slotted”在日常生活里常见于工具和器具：slotted screw（一字槽螺丝）、slotted screwdriver（一字螺丝刀）、slotted spoon（漏勺/漏网勺）。
在职场或日程语境里，slot表示“时间档/名额”，所以be slotted for…常指“被排到某个时段/岗位”。

summary.en: Slotting means fitting something into an available time or place, or arranging/placing items or people into positions or categories; it’s also a logistics term for product placement optimization.
summary.zh: Slotting 指把事情安排进可用的时间或位置，也可指把人/物放进某种位置或类别；在物流领域还指库位/陈列优化。

definition.en: the act of fitting something into an available time, place, or position (often in schedules)
definition.zh: 把某事安排进可用的时间/位置（常指日程安排）的行为

examples.en: We’re slotting the meeting in after lunch.
examples.zh: 我们把会议安排在午饭后。

examples.en: The editor is slotting your article into next week’s issue.
examples.zh: 编辑把你的文章安排进下周那一期。

definition.en: the act of classifying or placing someone/something into a category, role, or system
definition.zh: 把某人/某物归类、放进某种角色或体系的行为

examples.en: Slotting students by test scores can be unfair.
examples.zh: 按考试分数给学生分档可能不公平。

examples.en: It’s hard to avoid slotting people into stereotypes.
examples.zh: 很难完全避免把人归进刻板印象里。

definition.en: in logistics/retail, arranging products in specific storage or shelf locations to improve picking, stocking, or sales
definition.zh: （物流/零售）为提高拣货、补货或销售而对商品进行库位/货架位置规划与摆放

examples.en: Better slotting reduced the time workers spent walking in the warehouse.
examples.zh: 更好的库位规划减少了仓库员工的走动时间。

examples.en: They changed the slotting of snacks to increase impulse purchases.
examples.zh: 他们调整了零食的陈列位置以增加冲动消费。

extraExplanation: “slotting”来自动词“slot”（放入槽/空位）。日常口语里最常见的是“slot (someone/something) in”（硬挤出时间/位置安排进去）。
在供应链领域，“slotting”是常见术语，指库位优化（把高频商品放更容易拿取的位置）。在零售/品牌合作中还会出现“slotting fee/allowance”（上架费/陈列费）这一相关表达。

summary.en: “Slouch” means to sit/stand with a drooping posture, or the posture itself; it can also mean to move in a slow, lazy way.
summary.zh: “Slouch”指（坐/站时）驼背、懒散的姿势或这种姿势本身；也可指拖沓地走、懒洋洋地移动。

definition.en: to sit or stand with a lazy, drooping posture (shoulders rounded, body not upright)
definition.zh: （坐或站时）无精打采地弯腰驼背；懒散地塌着身子

examples.en: Try not to slouch when you’re at your desk; it can hurt your back.
examples.zh: 坐在书桌前尽量别驼背；这会伤到你的背。

examples.en: He slouched on the sofa and stared at the TV.
examples.zh: 他瘫坐在沙发上，盯着电视看。

definition.en: a lazy, drooping posture; the act of sitting or standing in that way
definition.zh: 驼背的姿势；懒散的坐姿/站姿

examples.en: His slouch made him look tired and uninterested.
examples.zh: 他那副驼背的样子让人觉得他很累、没兴趣。

examples.en: The coach corrected her slouch and told her to stand tall.
examples.zh: 教练纠正了她的驼背姿势，让她站直。

definition.en: to move in a slow, heavy, or lazy way
definition.zh: 拖沓地走；慢吞吞、懒洋洋地移动

examples.en: After the long hike, we slouched back to the car.
examples.zh: 长途徒步后，我们拖着疲惫的步子回到车里。

examples.en: He slouched into the room without saying hello.
examples.zh: 他拖沓地走进房间，连招呼都没打。

extraExplanation: “Slouch”常带有评价意味：不仅表示“姿势弯”，还常暗示“没精神、不自信或不在意”。在正式场合（面试、演讲、课堂）说“Don’t slouch.”往往是在提醒要显得更自信、更有礼貌。
常见搭配：slouch at the desk（在桌前驼背）、slouch on the couch/sofa（瘫在沙发上）、correct/fix your slouch（纠正驼背）。
相关表达：slump（更强调“瘫倒/塌下去”，也可指情绪低落或经济下滑）、hunch（弓着背把肩膀耸起来，常因冷或紧张）、sit up straight（坐直）、stand tall（站得挺拔）。

summary.en: Slough can mean a swampy place, or to shed/peel off, or to cast off something unwanted (often “slough off”).
summary.zh: Slough可指泥泞沼泽/回水湾；也可表示（皮肤等）脱落、蜕去；引申为摆脱不想要的东西（常用slough off）。

definition.en: a muddy, swampy area or a slow backwater channel (often next to a river)
definition.zh: 泥泞的沼泽地；（常在河边的）回水湾/支汊水道

examples.en: After heavy rain, the field turned into a slough.
examples.zh: 大雨过后，田地变成了一片泥沼。

examples.en: Birds nest in the slough along the river.
examples.zh: 鸟儿在河边的回水湾栖息筑巢。

definition.en: to shed or peel off naturally (especially skin, leaves, or an outer layer)
definition.zh: （皮肤、叶子或外层）自然脱落；蜕去

examples.en: Snakes slough their old skin as they grow.
examples.zh: 蛇在生长过程中会蜕去旧皮。

examples.en: The tree sloughed its bark after the cold winter.
examples.zh: 寒冬过后，那棵树的树皮脱落了。

definition.en: to get rid of something unwanted; to cast off (often in the phrase “slough off”)
definition.zh: 摆脱（不想要的东西）；甩掉（常用于短语“slough off”）

examples.en: He tried to slough off his bad habits.
examples.zh: 他努力改掉自己的坏习惯。

examples.en: The company sloughed off its old image and rebranded.
examples.zh: 公司摆脱了旧形象并重新塑造品牌。

extraExplanation: “slough”在美式英语里有两种常见读音：表示“沼泽/回水湾”时多读 /slaʊ/（像“plow”）；表示“脱落、摆脱（slough off）”时很多人读 /slʌf/（像“stuff”里的元音）。虽然这里给出一个IPA，但你在真实语境中可能会听到两种读法。
搭配提示：最常见短语是 **slough off**（摆脱、甩掉；也可指“脱落”），语气比“remove”更强调“自然脱去”或“把负担甩开”。
词源上与“剥落、去皮”相关，因此既能表示“泥沼（像一层难走的‘覆盖物’）”，也能表示“皮肤/外层的脱落”。

summary.en: “Sloven” means a very messy, unclean person (noun) or describing someone/something as habitually untidy and dirty (adjective).
summary.zh: “sloven”指非常邋遢、不讲卫生的人（名词），或形容（长期）不修边幅、脏乱的（形容词）。

definition.en: a person who is habitually messy, dirty, or careless about appearance and cleanliness
definition.zh: （常常）邋遢、不讲卫生或不修边幅的人

examples.en: He’s a bit of a sloven—his room is always full of dirty clothes.
examples.zh: 他有点邋遢——房间里总是堆满脏衣服。

examples.en: The boss warned him not to come to work looking like a sloven.
examples.zh: 老板警告他上班别再一副邋遢样。

definition.en: messy or careless about cleanliness and appearance; untidy
definition.zh: 邋遢的；不修边幅的；不讲卫生的

examples.en: She hated his sloven habits, like leaving dishes in the sink for days.
examples.zh: 她很讨厌他那些邋遢习惯，比如碗盘在水槽里一放就是好几天。

examples.en: He showed up in sloven clothes that looked unwashed.
examples.zh: 他穿着邋遢的衣服出现，看起来像没洗过。

extraExplanation: “sloven”通常带有强烈的负面评价，语气比“messy/untidy（有点乱）”更重，更像是在说“不讲卫生、长期邋遢”。在正式或当面场合使用时要注意礼貌。
词源上与“slow（慢）”有关，早期含义接近“懒散、拖拉”，后来逐渐引申为“邋遢、不修边幅”。

summary.en: Slovenia is a country in Central Europe; its capital is Ljubljana.
summary.zh: Slovenia 指中欧国家“斯洛文尼亚”，首都是卢布尔雅那。

definition.en: a country in Central Europe, bordering Italy, Austria, Hungary, and Croatia; its capital is Ljubljana
definition.zh: 斯洛文尼亚（中欧国家），与意大利、奥地利、匈牙利和克罗地亚接壤；首都是卢布尔雅那（Ljubljana）

examples.en: Slovenia joined the European Union in 2004.
examples.zh: 斯洛文尼亚于2004年加入欧盟。

examples.en: We traveled through Slovenia to see Lake Bled and the Julian Alps.
examples.zh: 我们穿越斯洛文尼亚，去看布莱德湖和朱利安阿尔卑斯山。

examples.en: Ljubljana is the capital city of Slovenia.
examples.zh: 卢布尔雅那是斯洛文尼亚的首都。

extraExplanation: 在英语里，国家名通常要大写：Slovenia。表示“斯洛文尼亚的/斯洛文尼亚人（的）”一般用形容词/名词 Slovenian（如：Slovenian food 斯洛文尼亚菜；a Slovenian 一位斯洛文尼亚人）。
Slovenia 位于巴尔干与中欧的交汇处，面积不大但地形多样：有阿尔卑斯山区、喀斯特地貌（karst）、以及一小段亚得里亚海海岸。
文化与语言：官方语言是斯洛文尼亚语（Slovene/Slovenian），货币为欧元（euro），也是申根区成员，旅行时常与周边国家一起规划路线。

summary.en: Slovenian means “from Slovenia” and can also refer to a person from Slovenia or the Slovene language.
summary.zh: Slovenian 表示“斯洛文尼亚的”，也可指“斯洛文尼亚人”或“斯洛文尼亚语（Slovene）”。

definition.en: Relating to Slovenia, its people, or its culture.
definition.zh: 斯洛文尼亚的；与斯洛文尼亚、其人民或文化有关的。

examples.en: Slovenian food often includes dishes like jota (a hearty soup).
examples.zh: 斯洛文尼亚美食中常见像 jota（浓汤）这样的菜肴。

examples.en: She visited a Slovenian museum in Ljubljana.
examples.zh: 她参观了卢布尔雅那的一家斯洛文尼亚博物馆。

definition.en: A person from Slovenia.
definition.zh: 斯洛文尼亚人。

examples.en: Two Slovenians joined the hiking group.
examples.zh: 有两位斯洛文尼亚人加入了徒步小队。

examples.en: He is Slovenian, but he lives in the U.S. now.
examples.zh: 他是斯洛文尼亚人，但现在住在美国。

definition.en: The South Slavic language spoken in Slovenia; Slovene.
definition.zh: 斯洛文尼亚语（亦称 Slovene），在斯洛文尼亚使用的南斯拉夫语支语言。

examples.en: I can say a few phrases in Slovenian.
examples.zh: 我会说几句斯洛文尼亚语。

examples.en: Slovenian uses the Latin alphabet.
examples.zh: 斯洛文尼亚语使用拉丁字母。

extraExplanation: “Slovenian”既可指“斯洛文尼亚的/斯洛文尼亚人”，也可指“斯洛文尼亚语”。在语言学或更正式的语境里，“Slovene”常专指语言（也可指民族/形容词），但日常英语里用“Slovenian”完全没问题。
注意不要与“Slovak/Slovakian（斯洛伐克的）”混淆：Slovenia（斯洛文尼亚）与 Slovakia（斯洛伐克）是两个不同国家。

summary.en: “Slovenly” means messy, untidy, and careless—especially about cleanliness or appearance.
summary.zh: “slovenly”表示邋遢、不整洁、做事马虎，尤其指不讲卫生或外表不修边幅。

definition.en: Messy, untidy, or careless in appearance or habits (especially about cleanliness).
definition.zh: 邋遢的；不整洁的；（尤指）不讲卫生、做事马虎的。

examples.en: His room was slovenly, with clothes on the floor and dishes on the desk.
examples.zh: 他的房间很邋遢，衣服扔在地上，盘子放在桌上。

examples.en: She apologized for her slovenly handwriting on the form.
examples.zh: 她为表格上潦草、不工整的字迹道了歉。

definition.en: In a messy or careless way.
definition.zh: 邋遢地；随便地；不整洁地（较少见用法）。

examples.en: He dressed slovenly for the interview and didn’t make a good impression.
examples.zh: 他面试时穿得很随便邋遢，没留下好印象。

extraExplanation: “slovenly”常用来批评一个人的外表、卫生习惯或做事方式不够认真。语气偏负面，但在较轻的语境里也可以只是客观描述“乱/不整洁”。
注意不要和“Slovenian（斯洛文尼亚的）”混淆：两者拼写相近但意思完全不同。
名词“sloven”指“邋遢的人”，较少在日常口语中使用；更常见的是形容词“slovenly”。

summary.en: “Slow” most commonly means “not fast,” and it can describe speed, progress, or (more sensitively) how quickly someone understands. It can also be an adverb (“drive slow”) and a verb (“slow down”).
summary.zh: “slow”最常见意思是“不快/缓慢”，可形容速度或进展；形容人时要注意语气，可能显得不礼貌。它也可作副词（drive slow）和动词（slow down）。

definition.en: moving, happening, or progressing at a low speed; not fast
definition.zh: 缓慢的；速度低的；不快的

examples.en: Traffic is really slow today.
examples.zh: 今天交通真的很慢。

examples.en: We took the slow train because it was cheaper.
examples.zh: 我们坐了慢车，因为更便宜。

definition.en: taking a long time; not quick to happen or finish
definition.zh: 耗时长的；进展慢的；不迅速完成的

examples.en: Service at this restaurant can be slow on weekends.
examples.zh: 这家餐厅周末服务可能会很慢。

examples.en: The recovery was slow but steady.
examples.zh: 康复过程很慢，但很稳定。

definition.en: not quick to understand, learn, or react (can sound rude; use carefully)
definition.zh: 反应慢的；理解/学习慢的（可能显得不礼貌，慎用）

examples.en: I’m a little slow today—I didn’t sleep well.
examples.zh: 我今天有点反应慢——没睡好。

examples.en: Please be patient with him; he’s slow to warm up in new situations.
examples.zh: 请对他有耐心；他在新环境里需要一点时间才能放开。

definition.en: at a low speed; not quickly
definition.zh: 慢慢地；不快地

examples.en: Drive slow in the snow.
examples.zh: 下雪天开车要慢点。

examples.en: He walked slow so the child could keep up.
examples.zh: 他走得很慢，好让孩子跟得上。

definition.en: to slow down; to reduce speed or the rate of progress
definition.zh: （使）变慢；减速；放缓进度

examples.en: The car slowed as it approached the school zone.
examples.zh: 车靠近学校区域时减速了。

examples.en: They slowed the pace of the project to avoid mistakes.
examples.zh: 他们放慢了项目进度，以避免错误。

extraExplanation: “slow”用来形容人时，可能带有“迟钝/笨”的贬义（例如“He’s slow.”）。更礼貌的说法常用："slow to understand"（理解需要时间）、"needs more time"（需要更多时间）、"not feeling sharp today"（今天状态不在线）。
口语里常见搭配："slow down"（慢下来/放慢）、"take it slow"（慢慢来/别急，也可指恋爱进展放慢）、"slow but sure"（慢但稳）。

summary.en: A slowdown is a decrease in speed or in the rate of activity or progress.
summary.zh: slowdown 指速度或活动/发展进程的下降与放缓。

definition.en: a reduction in speed, activity, or progress (especially in the economy, business, or traffic)
definition.zh: （速度、活动或进展的）放缓；（尤指经济、商业或交通的）减速/减缓

examples.en: There has been a slowdown in the housing market this year.
examples.zh: 今年房地产市场出现了放缓。

examples.en: A traffic accident caused a slowdown on the highway.
examples.zh: 一起交通事故导致高速公路车流变慢。

examples.en: After a period of rapid growth, the company saw a slowdown in sales.
examples.zh: 在一段快速增长之后，这家公司出现了销量放缓。

extraExplanation: “slowdown”也常写作“slowdown”或“slow-down”（带连字符的拼写较少见）。
注意区分名词“a slowdown”（一次/一种放缓）和动词短语“slow down”（放慢；减速）。例如：Please slow down.（请慢一点。）

summary.en: “Slowed” means “became slower” or “made something slower,” and it can also describe something that is moving at a reduced speed.
summary.zh: “slowed”表示“变慢了”或“使……变慢”，也可作形容词描述“速度放缓的状态”。

definition.en: Moved or happened more slowly than before; reduced in speed.
definition.zh: （速度）变慢了的；比之前更慢地移动或发生。

examples.en: Traffic slowed near the bridge.
examples.zh: 靠近桥时交通变慢了。

examples.en: Her breathing slowed after a few minutes of rest.
examples.zh: 休息几分钟后，她的呼吸变慢了。

definition.en: Past tense/past participle of “slow”: to make something go slower or to become slower.
definition.zh: “slow”的过去式/过去分词：使……变慢；（自己）变慢。

examples.en: He slowed the car as the school zone began.
examples.zh: 进入学校区域时，他把车速放慢了。

examples.en: The music slowed and the lights dimmed.
examples.zh: 音乐慢了下来，灯光也变暗了。

examples.en: The cold weather slowed our progress.
examples.zh: 寒冷的天气让我们的进度变慢了。

extraExplanation: “slowed”常见于叙事写作里，用来表达节奏变化：不只是速度变慢，也可能暗示情绪缓和、紧张感下降，或时间感被拉长（例如："Time seemed to slow."）。
区分用法：作动词时常见结构是“slow + 事物”（slowed the car）或“slow down”（slowed down）；作形容词时常见搭配有“slowed growth / slowed progress”（放缓的增长/进展）。

summary.en: “Slower” is the comparative form of “slow,” meaning more slow or less quickly.
summary.zh: “slower”是“slow”的比较级，表示“更慢的/更慢地”。

definition.en: More slow; moving, happening, or done at a lower speed than something else.
definition.zh: 更慢的；比其他事物移动、发生或完成得更慢的。

examples.en: This computer is slower than my old one.
examples.zh: 这台电脑比我旧的那台更慢。

examples.en: Traffic is slower on Fridays.
examples.zh: 周五的交通更慢。

definition.en: At a lower speed than something else; less quickly.
definition.zh: 更慢地；比其他情况更不快地。

examples.en: Please drive slower in the neighborhood.
examples.zh: 请在居民区开慢一点。

examples.en: If you speak slower, I can understand you better.
examples.zh: 如果你说慢一点，我就能更好理解你。

definition.en: A person or thing that is slow (informal and sometimes rude).
definition.zh: 慢的人/东西（非正式用法，有时带不礼貌或贬义）。

examples.en: Don’t call him a slower—he’s just learning.
examples.zh: 别叫他“慢吞吞的人”——他只是在学习而已。

extraExplanation: “slower”通常是形容词/副词“slow”的比较级：slow → slower → slowest。
口语里常说“slow down”（慢下来）。注意：英语里直接说“a slower”来指人不常见，也可能显得冒犯；更自然的说法是“a slow person”或用更中性的表达。

summary.en: “Slowest” means the least fast—the superlative form of “slow.”
summary.zh: “slowest”表示“最慢的”，是“slow”的最高级。

definition.en: Superlative form of “slow”; the least fast, taking the most time compared with others.
definition.zh: “slow”的最高级；最慢的、最不快的（与其他相比花时间最多）。

examples.en: This is the slowest computer in the office.
examples.zh: 这是办公室里最慢的电脑。

examples.en: He was the slowest runner on the team, but he never gave up.
examples.zh: 他是队里跑得最慢的，但他从不放弃。

examples.en: Today’s traffic was the slowest I’ve seen all month.
examples.zh: 今天的交通是我这个月见过最慢的一次。

definition.en: Doing something with the least speed; in the most unhurried way (often describing how an action happens).
definition.zh: 以最慢的速度做（某事）；最不慌不忙地（常用来描述动作发生的方式）。

examples.en: Please walk slowest near the ice so you don’t slip.
examples.zh: 在冰面附近请走得最慢些，以免滑倒。

examples.en: Of all the elevators, this one moves the slowest.
examples.zh: 在所有电梯里，这一部动得最慢。

extraExplanation: “slowest”通常用于三者及以上的比较（the slowest + 名词）。两者比较一般用“slower”。
当“slowest”作副词使用时，日常英语更常说“(the) most slowly”。例如：This elevator moves the most slowly.（更自然）

summary.en: “Slowly” means “not fast,” and it can also mean “gradually over time.”
summary.zh: “slowly”表示“慢慢地、不快地”，也可表示“逐渐地（随时间慢慢发生）”。

definition.en: At a slow speed; not quickly.
definition.zh: 慢慢地；以较慢的速度；不快地。

examples.en: Please speak slowly—I’m still learning English.
examples.zh: 请说慢一点——我还在学英语。

examples.en: The car moved slowly through traffic.
examples.zh: 车在车流中缓慢行驶。

examples.en: She slowly opened the letter, nervous about the news.
examples.zh: 她紧张地慢慢打开信，担心里面的消息。

definition.en: Gradually, over time (often describing change or development).
definition.zh: 逐渐地；渐渐地（常描述变化或发展）。

examples.en: He is slowly getting better after the illness.
examples.zh: 他生病后正在逐渐好转。

examples.en: Trust builds slowly, especially after a mistake.
examples.zh: 信任建立得很慢，尤其是在犯错之后。

extraExplanation: “slowly”既可以表示“速度慢”（动作做得慢），也可以表示“变化慢/逐渐发生”（过程慢）。学习者常把它只理解成“慢慢走/慢慢说”，但在描述恢复、增长、建立关系等抽象过程时也很常用。
语气上，“slowly”有时能营造紧张或戏剧感：比如“slowly opened the door/letter”暗示人物犹豫、害怕或期待。

summary.en: “Slows” usually means “becomes slower” or “makes something slower.”
summary.zh: “slows”通常表示“变慢/减速”或“使……变慢”（多为动词第三人称单数）。

definition.en: to become slower; to move or happen with less speed
definition.zh: （速度或进程）变慢；减速

examples.en: Traffic slows near the school in the morning.
examples.zh: 早上学校附近的车流会变慢。

examples.en: As winter comes, plant growth slows.
examples.zh: 冬天来临时，植物生长会变慢。

definition.en: to make something slower; to reduce the speed of something
definition.zh: 使……变慢；放慢（某物的速度）

examples.en: The driver slows the car before the turn.
examples.zh: 司机在转弯前放慢车速。

examples.en: New rules may slow the project.
examples.zh: 新规定可能会拖慢项目进度。

definition.en: the slower parts, moments, or activities (plural of “slow,” less common)
definition.zh: 较慢的部分/时段/活动（“slow”的复数，用法较少）

examples.en: The movie has a few slows in the middle, but the ending is strong.
examples.zh: 这部电影中段有几处节奏较慢，但结尾很精彩。

extraExplanation: “slows”最常见是动词“slow”的第三人称单数（he/she/it slows）。比如：It slows down. / She slows the pace.
常见搭配：slow down（慢下来）、slow to do sth（迟迟才……）、slow in doing sth（在……方面动作慢）。注意：slow vs. slowly——slow可作形容词/副词（口语里如 “Drive slow.”），slowly更常见作副词（更正式）。

summary.en: Slug can mean a shell-less garden animal, a bullet, an informal term for a lazy person, or the verb “to hit hard” (and sometimes “to drink quickly”).
summary.zh: slug 可指“蛞蝓/鼻涕虫”、 “弹头”，也可口语指“懒虫/动作慢的人”；作动词可表示“猛击”，有时也指“猛灌（喝）”。

definition.en: a small, soft-bodied animal like a snail but without a shell, often found in gardens
definition.zh: 蛞蝓；鼻涕虫（类似蜗牛但没有壳，常见于花园）

examples.en: A slug was eating the lettuce in the garden.
examples.zh: 一只蛞蝓在花园里啃生菜。

examples.en: After the rain, slugs come out onto the sidewalk.
examples.zh: 下雨后，蛞蝓会爬到人行道上。

definition.en: a hard piece of metal fired from a gun (a bullet), or a solid metal weight/shot
definition.zh: （枪的）弹头；（某些用法中）金属弹丸/铅弹

examples.en: The police found a slug in the wall.
examples.zh: 警方在墙里发现了一枚弹头。

examples.en: The hunter used slugs instead of birdshot.
examples.zh: 猎人用的是独头弹（slug），而不是散弹。

definition.en: an informal word for a lazy or slow person
definition.zh: （非正式）懒汉；动作慢的人

examples.en: Come on, you slug—get out of bed!
examples.zh: 快点啊，你这懒虫——起床！

examples.en: I felt like a slug after staying up late.
examples.zh: 熬夜之后我感觉自己像条“懒虫”。

definition.en: to hit someone hard, usually with your hand or fist
definition.zh: 猛击；重拳打

examples.en: He slugged the man who insulted him.
examples.zh: 他一拳打向那个侮辱他的人。

examples.en: The boxer slugged his opponent in the ribs.
examples.zh: 拳击手猛击对手的肋部。

definition.en: to drink something quickly and in large amounts (often used with “down”)
definition.zh: （常与 down 连用）猛灌；一口气喝下

examples.en: She slugged down a glass of water after the run.
examples.zh: 跑完步后她一口气灌下一杯水。

examples.en: Don’t slug your drink—sip it slowly.
examples.zh: 别猛灌，慢慢喝。

extraExplanation: “slug”做“蛞蝓”是最直观的具体含义；在口语里把人叫“a slug”通常带点责备或玩笑，语气不算礼貌，建议只对熟人使用。
“slug”（弹头）在新闻、警察报告或枪械语境更常见；日常更常说“bullet”。
动词“slug”=“重击”很口语，也常出现在体育报道里；“slug down”表示“猛喝”，语气随意，正式写作可用“drink quickly / gulp”。

summary.en: A “sluggard” is a lazy person who is slow to work or take action.
summary.zh: “sluggard”指懒惰、做事拖拉的人，语气较强，常用于批评。

definition.en: A person who is habitually lazy and slow to act or work.
definition.zh: 懒惰而行动迟缓的人；懒汉。

examples.en: He’s not stupid—he’s just a sluggard who avoids hard work.
examples.zh: 他不笨——他只是个懒汉，刻意躲着辛苦的工作。

examples.en: The coach warned that a sluggard can’t stay on the team.
examples.zh: 教练警告说，懒散的人不能留在队里。

examples.en: She didn’t want to be seen as a sluggard, so she started showing up early.
examples.zh: 她不想被看成懒散的人，所以开始提前到场。

extraExplanation: “sluggard”带有比较强的批评语气，常见于较正式或带道德劝诫的语境。它在《圣经·箴言》(Proverbs) 中多次出现，用来劝人勤奋、不要懒惰，因此在英语里常带一点“劝诫/警醒”的文化色彩。

summary.en: A slugger is usually a powerful baseball hitter, and it can also mean a hard hitter (like a boxer) or, informally, a lazy person.
summary.zh: slugger 通常指（棒球）强打者；也可指重拳手/施暴者；口语里还可指懒汉或慢吞吞的人。

definition.en: a strong hitter in baseball, especially someone known for hitting many home runs
definition.zh: （棒球）强打者；本垒打好手（以力量和全垒打著称的打者）

examples.en: He’s one of the best sluggers in the league, with 40 home runs this season.
examples.zh: 他是联盟里最强的强打者之一，这个赛季打了40支全垒打。

examples.en: The team needs a slugger in the middle of the lineup.
examples.zh: 球队需要在打线中段安排一位强打者。

definition.en: a person who hits hard, especially a boxer or someone who attacks others
definition.zh: 重拳手；狠揍他人的人（尤指拳击手或施暴者）

examples.en: He was a slugger in the ring, known for powerful punches.
examples.zh: 他在拳台上是个重拳手，以拳头力量大著称。

examples.en: Police were looking for the slugger who attacked the man outside the store.
examples.zh: 警方正在寻找在商店外袭击那名男子的施暴者。

definition.en: (informal) a lazy or slow person
definition.zh: （非正式）懒汉；慢吞吞的人

examples.en: Stop being a slugger and get moving—we’re late!
examples.zh: 别这么懒散了，快动起来——我们要迟到了！

extraExplanation: 在美式英语里，slugger 最常见于棒球语境，指“强打者”。常见搭配有：power slugger（重炮型强打者）、home-run slugger（全垒打型强打者）。
词根来自动词 slug（猛击；重打），所以引申出“重拳手/打人者”。不同语境下语气差很多：体育报道多为褒义（强打者），谈到暴力攻击时则是负面用法。

summary.en: Sluggish means slow and lacking energy, or (for liquids) slow-flowing and thick.
summary.zh: Sluggish 指“缓慢、没精神/反应迟钝”，也可指（液体）“流动慢、较黏稠”。

definition.en: Moving, working, or responding slowly; lacking energy or speed.
definition.zh: 缓慢的；行动/反应迟钝的；没精神的。

examples.en: I felt sluggish after lunch and couldn’t focus on my work.
examples.zh: 午饭后我觉得很没精神，没法专心工作。

examples.en: The old laptop is sluggish when I open too many tabs.
examples.zh: 这个旧笔记本电脑开太多标签页就会变得很卡、反应很慢。

examples.en: Business was sluggish during the rainy season.
examples.zh: 雨季期间生意很冷清、进展缓慢。

definition.en: (Of a liquid) flowing slowly; thick or not moving easily.
definition.zh: （液体）流动缓慢的；黏稠而不易流动的。

examples.en: In cold weather, the oil becomes more sluggish.
examples.zh: 天气冷时，油会变得更黏稠、流动更慢。

examples.en: The sauce was sluggish and wouldn’t pour out easily.
examples.zh: 酱汁很稠，不容易倒出来。

extraExplanation: “sluggish”常用来形容人“没劲、提不起精神”（像困、累、反应慢），也常形容机器/网络“卡顿、慢”。形容经济或市场时，语气更偏“低迷、不活跃”。
词源上来自“slug（蛞蝓/行动慢的人）”，所以带有“像蛞蝓一样慢”的形象感；日常描述人时一般不算很刻薄，但用于评价某人工作效率时可能显得批评。

summary.en: Slughorn is the surname of Horace Slughorn, a Hogwarts teacher in the Harry Potter series; it can also be used informally to describe a person who collects talented, well-connected people for networking.
summary.zh: Slughorn 是《哈利·波特》中霍拉斯·斯拉格霍恩的姓；也可引申为形容爱网罗人才、经营人脉圈的人。

definition.en: (Proper noun) Horace Slughorn, a fictional character (a Hogwarts teacher) in J.K. Rowling’s Harry Potter series; his last name is often used to refer to him in fan discussions.
definition.zh: （专有名词）霍拉斯·斯拉格霍恩（Horace Slughorn），J.K. 罗琳《哈利·波特》系列中的虚构人物（霍格沃茨教师）；在讨论中常用其姓氏“Slughorn”指代他本人。

examples.en: Slughorn becomes an important character in Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince.
examples.zh: 斯拉格霍恩在《哈利·波特与混血王子》中成为重要角色。

examples.en: Many fans remember Slughorn for hosting the “Slug Club.”
examples.zh: 许多粉丝记得斯拉格霍恩主持过“鼻涕虫俱乐部（Slug Club）”。

definition.en: (By extension, informal) Someone who collects talented or well-connected people and builds a network around them (based on the character’s behavior).
definition.zh: （引申用法，非正式）指喜欢“网罗”有才华或有人脉的人、并围绕他们建立关系网的人（源于该角色的行为特点）。

examples.en: He’s a bit of a Slughorn—always inviting the top students to private events.
examples.zh: 他有点“斯拉格霍恩式”的作风——总爱邀请最优秀的学生参加私下聚会。

examples.en: The company’s recruiter acted like a Slughorn, trying to collect rising stars.
examples.zh: 公司的招聘负责人像个“Slughorn”，想把冉冉升起的新星都招揽过来。

extraExplanation: “Slughorn”这个姓带有一种形象化的感觉：slug=“鼻涕虫”，horn=“角/号角”。在故事里，斯拉格霍恩常被刻画为精于社交、喜欢结交“未来会成功的人”，因此粉丝或读者有时会把他的名字当作一种比喻。
相关表达：Slug Club（鼻涕虫俱乐部/斯拉格霍恩组织的精英小圈子）。
文学/文化出处：出自 J.K. Rowling 的 Harry Potter 系列，主要在《Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince》（《混血王子》）中登场较多。

summary.en: A sluice is a water-control gate/channel; it can also mean to flush with water, and in mining it’s a channel for separating minerals.
summary.zh: sluice 指控制水流的水闸/泄水道；也可作动词表示用水冲洗或放水；采矿中还指用于淘洗分离矿物的淘槽。

definition.en: A gate or channel that controls the flow of water, especially in a river, canal, or dam.
definition.zh: （尤指河流、运河或水坝的）水闸；泄水道，用来控制水流。

examples.en: The workers opened the sluice to release water from the canal.
examples.zh: 工人打开水闸，把运河里的水放出去。

examples.en: A broken sluice gate caused the fields to flood.
examples.zh: 坏掉的闸门导致田地被淹。

definition.en: To wash or flush something with a strong flow of water; to let water flow through a channel.
definition.zh: 用急水冲洗；放水（使水通过水道/闸门流动）。

examples.en: They sluiced the muddy floor clean with buckets of water.
examples.zh: 他们用一桶桶水把泥地冲洗干净。

examples.en: After the storm, the dam operators sluiced water to reduce pressure.
examples.zh: 暴风雨后，水坝操作员放水以减轻压力。

definition.en: A long, narrow channel used to direct water, often in mining to separate gold or other minerals from soil.
definition.zh: （采矿用）淘槽；溜槽（用水流分离金等矿物与泥沙）。

examples.en: During the gold rush, miners built a wooden sluice to catch flakes of gold.
examples.zh: 淘金热时期，矿工搭建木制淘槽来截留金屑。

extraExplanation: “sluice”常见搭配：sluice gate（闸门）、open/close the sluice（开/关闸放水）、sluice out（把……冲出去；把……冲洗掉）。
词源上与“sluce/sluys（排水通道）”有关，常用于水利工程语境；在历史上也常出现在淘金（gold rush）相关叙述里。

summary.en: “Slum” most commonly means a very poor, crowded city area; it can also mean to loiter or live lazily (informal).
summary.zh: “slum”最常指城市中的贫民窟/棚户区；也可作动词，表示（非正式）闲逛或懒散度日。

definition.en: a very poor and crowded area of a city, often with bad housing and limited services
definition.zh: （城市中的）贫民窟；棚户区（通常拥挤、住房条件差、公共服务不足）

examples.en: Many families in the slum have limited access to clean water.
examples.zh: 贫民窟里的许多家庭很难获得干净的饮用水。

examples.en: The charity works in slum neighborhoods to provide medical care.
examples.zh: 这家慈善机构在贫民窟社区提供医疗服务。

definition.en: to spend time doing nothing useful; to live lazily (informal, often disapproving)
definition.zh: （非正式，常带贬义）闲逛；游荡；懒散度日

examples.en: They slummed around all weekend instead of studying.
examples.zh: 他们整个周末都在闲晃，没有学习。

extraExplanation: “slum”用于指城市贫困地区时，常与社会不平等、住房政策、公共卫生等议题相关。写作或讨论时注意语气：它多为描述性用语，但也可能带有负面刻板印象；在新闻或学术语境中也常用“informal settlements（非正规住区）”“low-income neighborhoods（低收入社区）”等更中性的表达。
历史上，“slum”在19世纪英国城市化背景中使用增多，后来广泛用于描述世界各地的城市贫困聚居区。

summary.en: “Slum” usually means a very poor, overcrowded city area; as a verb, it can mean spending time in such places (often critically).
summary.zh: “slum” 通常指城市里的贫民窟；作动词时可指去这类地方逗留（常带批评语气）。

definition.en: a very poor and crowded area of a city, where housing is in bad condition
definition.zh: （城市里的）贫民窟；棚户区（房屋破旧、拥挤、贫困的地区）

examples.en: Many families in the slum don’t have clean water.
examples.zh: 贫民窟里的许多家庭没有干净的水。

examples.en: She volunteers at a school in a nearby slum.
examples.zh: 她在附近贫民窟的一所学校做志愿者。

definition.en: to live in or spend time in a place that is dirty, poor, or unpleasant (often used critically)
definition.zh: （常带批评）在肮脏、贫穷或令人不快的地方居住／消磨时间

examples.en: He was accused of slumming in poor neighborhoods for “adventure.”
examples.zh: 他被指责为了“寻刺激”而去贫困社区闲逛。

examples.en: They stopped slumming after they found a safer apartment.
examples.zh: 找到更安全的公寓后，他们就不再住在那种糟糕的地方了。

extraExplanation: “sluma” 不是常见的英语单词拼写。你可能想查的是 **slum**（贫民窟）或 **slumber**（睡觉、打盹）。如果你告诉我你看到 “sluma” 的句子或语境，我可以帮你确认正确词和意思。
名词 **slum** 偏中性描述现实；动词 **slum**（slumming）常带价值判断，使用时要注意语气与文化敏感性，避免把贫困当作“猎奇体验”。

summary.en: Slumber means a peaceful sleep (noun) or to sleep in a gentle, literary way (verb).
summary.zh: Slumber 指“安静的睡眠”（名词），也可作动词表示“（带文学色彩地）睡觉/沉睡”。

definition.en: Sleep, especially a gentle or peaceful kind of sleep.
definition.zh: 睡眠；（尤指）安静、平和的睡眠。

examples.en: The baby fell into a deep slumber after the long trip.
examples.zh: 长途旅行后，宝宝沉沉地睡着了。

examples.en: He was awakened from his slumber by a sudden noise.
examples.zh: 一阵突如其来的声音把他从睡梦中惊醒。

definition.en: To sleep, often used in a literary or gentle way.
definition.zh: 睡觉；（常用于较文学、较柔和的表达）入睡。

examples.en: She slumbered peacefully through the night.
examples.zh: 她整夜睡得很安稳。

examples.en: The city seems to slumber in the early hours of the morning.
examples.zh: 清晨时分，这座城市仿佛还在沉睡。

extraExplanation: “slumber”比“sleep”更带有“安宁、柔和、诗意”的感觉，常见搭配有“deep slumber（酣睡）”“peaceful slumber（安睡）”。
文学或诗歌中常用“slumber”来描写人或城市、自然“沉睡”的意象，因此也常用于拟人化表达。

summary.en: “Slumbered” means “slept” in a more literary/gentle way, and it can also mean something stayed inactive for a while.
summary.zh: “Slumbered”是 slumber 的过去式/过去分词，表示较文学、较委婉的“睡着了”；也可指某事物一段时间“沉寂/搁置”。

definition.en: to sleep (often used as a more literary or gentle way to say “slept”)
definition.zh: 睡着；睡眠（常用于较文学或较委婉的表达，等同于 slept）

examples.en: After the long journey, she slumbered on the train.
examples.zh: 长途旅行后，她在火车上睡着了。

examples.en: The baby slumbered peacefully in his crib.
examples.zh: 宝宝在婴儿床里安静地睡着了。

definition.en: to be inactive or not used for a period of time (often about plans, problems, or feelings)
definition.zh: 沉寂；搁置；暂时不起作用（常指计划、问题或情绪等一段时间不活跃）

examples.en: The old argument slumbered for years, then returned during the meeting.
examples.zh: 那场旧争论沉寂了多年，却在会议上又冒了出来。

examples.en: The project slumbered until new funding arrived.
examples.zh: 这个项目一直搁置，直到新的资金到位。

extraExplanation: “slumbered”是“slumber”的过去式/过去分词，比“slept”更偏文学、叙述或诗意语气，常用来营造安静、柔和的氛围（如小说描写人物入睡）。
第二个意思（“沉寂/搁置”）常用于抽象事物：例如 a plan slumbered（计划搁置）、a dispute slumbered（争端暂息）。

summary.en: “Slumbering” means “sleeping” or “inactive for now,” and it can also be the -ing form of the verb “slumber” (to sleep peacefully).
summary.zh: “slumbering”表示“正在安睡的”或“暂时不活跃的”；也可作动词 slumber 的现在分词，意为“安睡”。

definition.en: sleeping or seeming to be asleep; not active at the moment.
definition.zh: 睡着的；似乎在睡；（暂时）不活跃的。

examples.en: The baby lay slumbering in her crib.
examples.zh: 宝宝躺在婴儿床里睡得正香。

examples.en: A slumbering volcano can become dangerous again.
examples.zh: 一座“沉睡”的火山可能会再次变得危险。

examples.en: The project was slumbering until someone revived it.
examples.zh: 这个项目一直搁置着，直到有人把它重新启动。

definition.en: to sleep, often softly or peacefully.
definition.zh: 睡觉；安睡（常带“睡得香、睡得沉”的感觉）。

examples.en: He was slumbering on the couch when I got home.
examples.zh: 我到家时，他正躺在沙发上睡着。

examples.en: After the long trip, she slumbered deeply.
examples.zh: 长途旅行后，她睡得很沉。

extraExplanation: “slumber”比“sleep”更偏书面或文艺，常用来强调“安静、平和、香甜的睡”。因此你会在故事、诗歌或新闻里看到“slumbering”来形容“沉睡的城市/火山/危机”等带有画面感的表达。
常见搭配：slumbering giant（沉睡的巨人＝暂时未显露力量的人/事物），slumbering volcano（沉睡的火山），slumbering economy/market（不活跃的经济/市场）。
语体提示：日常口语里更常说“sleeping”。“slumbering”会显得更正式或更有文学色彩。

summary.en: Slumberous means sleepy or gently quiet and slow, often used in more literary descriptions.
summary.zh: Slumberous 指“昏昏欲睡的”或“宁静缓慢的”，常见于较文学化的描写。

definition.en: Sleepy, drowsy, or likely to make you feel like sleeping.
definition.zh: 昏昏欲睡的；困倦的；让人想睡的。

examples.en: After lunch, I often feel slumberous in the warm afternoon sun.
examples.zh: 午饭后，在温暖的午后阳光下我常常觉得昏昏欲睡。

examples.en: The slumberous music made the room quiet and calm.
examples.zh: 那段催眠般的音乐让房间变得安静而平和。

definition.en: Quiet and slow-moving, with little activity (often describing a place or time).
definition.zh: （地方或时光）宁静缓慢的；活动很少的。

examples.en: They spent the summer in a slumberous seaside town.
examples.zh: 他们在一个宁静缓慢的海边小镇度过了夏天。

examples.en: The slumberous pace of the village life felt relaxing.
examples.zh: 乡村生活那种慢悠悠的节奏让人很放松。

extraExplanation: “slumberous”来自“slumber”（睡眠、酣睡），语气比常见的“sleepy”更偏文学/描写性，常用来营造一种柔和、安静、带点催眠感的氛围（如：slumberous heat / slumberous afternoon）。
常见近义词区分：sleepy（口语常用：困）；drowsy（更强调困到眼皮打架、药物或疲劳导致的昏沉）；somnolent（更正式/医学或文学：嗜睡、困倦）；slumberous（更诗意：像要进入“酣睡”那样的倦意或宁静）。

summary.en: “Slumbers” means periods of sleep (noun) or “sleeps” (verb), often with a peaceful, poetic feeling.
summary.zh: “slumbers”可表示“睡眠/酣睡”（名词复数），也可作动词表示“睡着/安睡”（第三人称单数），语气常更宁静、更具文学感。

definition.en: (plural noun) periods of sleep, often suggesting calm, gentle, or natural sleep
definition.zh: （复数名词）睡眠；酣睡（常带有“宁静、温和”的语气）

examples.en: The baby’s slumbers were interrupted by the phone.
examples.zh: 宝宝的睡眠被电话声打断了。

examples.en: After the long trip, she finally fell into deep slumbers.
examples.zh: 长途旅行后，她终于沉沉睡去。

definition.en: (verb, third-person singular) to sleep, especially in a quiet or peaceful way
definition.zh: （动词第三人称单数）睡觉；安睡（尤指安静、平和地睡）

examples.en: He slumbers on the couch after dinner.
examples.zh: 他晚饭后在沙发上睡着了。

examples.en: The town slumbers through the hot afternoon.
examples.zh: 小镇在炎热的午后显得昏昏欲睡。

extraExplanation: “slumber”比“sleep”更有文学/诗意色彩，常用来表达“安静、柔和、带画面感的睡”，也可以引申为“沉寂/停滞”（如：The city slumbers）。

summary.en: “Slumber” means to sleep lightly (to doze) or a light, peaceful sleep; it often sounds more literary than “sleep.”
summary.zh: “slumber” 指“小睡/打盹”或“浅而安静的睡眠”，语气常比 “sleep” 更书面、更有文学色彩。

definition.en: to sleep lightly or for a short time; to doze
definition.zh: 小睡；打盹；浅睡

examples.en: I fell into a slumber on the train.
examples.zh: 我在火车上打了个盹。

examples.en: The baby slumbered peacefully in her crib.
examples.zh: 宝宝在婴儿床里安静地睡着。

examples.en: He was slumbering during the long lecture.
examples.zh: 他在冗长的讲座中打瞌睡。

definition.en: a light or peaceful sleep
definition.zh: 小睡；浅眠；安静的睡眠

examples.en: After lunch, she took a short slumber.
examples.zh: 午饭后，她小睡了一会儿。

examples.en: The city was in slumber at midnight.
examples.zh: 午夜时分，这座城市沉睡着。

extraExplanation: “slumeren”不是常见英语拼写，更像是荷兰语动词，意思接近“打盹/小睡”。英语里最接近、最常用的词是 **slumber**。
**slumber** 比 **sleep** 更偏书面、文学或带有“安静、轻柔”的感觉；也常用于拟人化表达，比如 “the city is in slumber（城市沉睡）”。
常见搭配：**fall into a slumber**（进入睡眠/睡着）、**peaceful slumber**（安睡）、**slumber party**（睡衣派对，朋友在别人家过夜聚会）。

summary.en: “Slumming” usually means visiting poor areas out of curiosity/entertainment (often criticized as insensitive), and it can also mean living in very poor conditions.
summary.zh: “slumming”通常指出于好奇或娱乐去贫困地区“体验/闲逛”（常带贬义），也可指在很差的居住条件下生活。

definition.en: (Gerund/verb form) Visiting poor or working-class neighborhoods for entertainment, curiosity, or “experience,” often in a way that feels insensitive or exploitative.
definition.zh: （动名词/动词形式）为了娱乐、好奇或“体验”而去贫困或工人阶级社区闲逛/参观，常带有不够尊重、甚至利用他人处境的意味。

examples.en: Some tourists were criticized for slumming in the area just to take photos.
examples.zh: 一些游客因到那片地区“体验贫困”只为拍照而受到批评。

examples.en: The article argues that slumming turns real hardship into entertainment.
examples.zh: 这篇文章认为，“体验贫困式的闲逛”把真实的艰难生活变成了娱乐。

definition.en: (Present participle) Living in a very poor or overcrowded place; existing under “slum” conditions.
definition.zh: （现在分词）住在非常贫穷或拥挤的地方；处于“贫民窟式”的居住条件中。

examples.en: They feared their relatives were slumming in unsafe housing after losing their jobs.
examples.zh: 他们担心亲人在失业后住进了不安全的廉价住所，生活条件很差。

definition.en: (Noun) The activity or practice of “going slumming.”
definition.zh: （名词）“去贫困地区闲逛/体验”的活动或做法。

examples.en: The film was criticized for encouraging slumming rather than understanding the community.
examples.zh: 这部电影被批评为鼓励“去体验贫困”，而不是去理解当地社区。

synonyms: living in squalor (for the ‘living poorly’ sense)
extraExplanation: “slumming”常被认为带有阶级优越感：把他人的贫困当作“景点”或刺激体验。在写作或交流中，若要表达“去了解某个社区/做田野调查/参加社区活动”，更中性的说法有：visit the neighborhood, spend time in the community, community tour（需看语境）, volunteer in the area。
词源上与“slum（贫民窟）”有关；19世纪末到20世纪初英语里常指富人去贫民区“猎奇式”游览，因此语气往往偏负面，使用时要注意语境与尊重。

summary.en: “Slump” means a downturn or a tired, drooping movement/posture; it can describe both performance decline and the way someone collapses into a seat.
summary.zh: “slump”既可指（业绩、经济等）低迷下滑，也可指人因疲惫而耷拉、瘫坐的动作或姿态。

definition.en: a period when something becomes weaker or less successful (for example, the economy, sales, or a team’s performance)
definition.zh: （经济、销量、球队表现等的）低迷期；不景气；衰退

examples.en: The company is trying to recover from a sales slump.
examples.zh: 公司正努力从销量低迷中恢复。

examples.en: After a strong start, the team hit a slump in midseason.
examples.zh: 开局强劲之后，球队在赛季中段陷入低迷。

definition.en: to sit, stand, or fall in a loose, tired way; to drop heavily into a seat
definition.zh: 无精打采地坐/站/倒下；（疲惫地）一屁股坐下

examples.en: He slumped into the chair after work.
examples.zh: 下班后他疲惫地瘫坐在椅子上。

examples.en: She slumped forward, exhausted.
examples.zh: 她累得向前耷拉着身子。

definition.en: to become less active, less successful, or lower in value
definition.zh: 变得不景气；走弱；下滑

examples.en: Demand for the product slumped last month.
examples.zh: 上个月该产品的需求下滑了。

extraExplanation: “slump”既可形容身体姿势（疲惫、没精神地“瘫”着），也常用于商业/经济语境表示“低迷、下滑”。语气比“decline”更口语、更有“突然变差或一段时间很差”的感觉。
常见搭配：a sales/economic slump（销量/经济低迷）；hit/fall into a slump（陷入低迷）；slump in demand/prices（需求/价格下滑）。在体育中也常说 a batting slump（打击低潮）。

summary.en: “Slumped” describes someone sitting/standing in a drooping, tired posture, or having fallen/sunk down heavily; it’s the past form of “slump.”
summary.zh: “slumped”表示（人）疲惫/沮丧地瘫坐、耷拉着，或无力地倒下/下沉；是“slump”的过去式/过去分词。

definition.en: To sit, stand, or move in a drooping, heavy, or tired way (often with shoulders rounded).
definition.zh: （因疲惫、沮丧或无力而）耷拉着坐/站/走，身体下塌。

examples.en: After the long exam, he slumped in his chair.
examples.zh: 考完那场很长的考试后，他瘫坐在椅子上。

examples.en: She slumped against the wall, exhausted.
examples.zh: 她精疲力尽地靠着墙瘫了下来。

definition.en: Past tense or past participle of “slump”; describes someone or something in a drooping, collapsed posture.
definition.zh: “slump”的过去式/过去分词；形容（人或物）呈现下塌、无力的姿态。

examples.en: He was slumped over the table, half asleep.
examples.zh: 他趴在桌子上，半睡半醒。

examples.en: A slumped figure waited at the bus stop in the rain.
examples.zh: 一个蜷缩无力的身影在雨中公交站等车。

definition.en: To fall or sink suddenly, often in a weak or uncontrolled way.
definition.zh: （突然）下陷、跌落（常带有无力或失控的感觉）。

examples.en: The tired runner slumped to the ground after finishing.
examples.zh: 那位疲惫的跑者冲线后一下子瘫倒在地。

extraExplanation: “slump”常用来表达两类含义：①身体姿态的“瘫/耷拉”；②状态或数值的“骤降”（如sales slumped 销量下滑）。你给的“slumped”在叙述里很常见，用来快速传达疲惫、沮丧、失落等情绪。

summary.en: “Slumping” usually means sitting/standing in a drooping way, or (in business/news) falling quickly.
summary.zh: “slumping”通常指（姿势）塌着坐/站，也可指（经济数据等）快速下滑。

definition.en: Sitting or standing in a drooping, collapsed way (often showing tiredness, boredom, sadness, or poor posture).
definition.zh: （坐或站时）无精打采地塌着/佝偻着（常表示疲惫、无聊、难过或姿势不良）。

examples.en: He was slumping on the sofa after a long day at work.
examples.zh: 他工作了一整天后瘫坐在沙发上。

examples.en: Stop slumping at your desk—sit up straight.
examples.zh: 别在书桌前塌着坐——坐直。

definition.en: The action of sitting, standing, or leaning with shoulders and body drooping; the present participle of “slump.”
definition.zh: （身体）耷拉下垮、塌陷的动作；“slump”的现在分词。

examples.en: She kept slumping forward during the lecture because she was sleepy.
examples.zh: 她上课时一直往前塌，因为太困了。

examples.en: I noticed I was slumping, so I adjusted my chair.
examples.zh: 我发现自己坐姿塌了，就调整了椅子。

definition.en: Falling or decreasing quickly (often used for prices, sales, confidence, or performance).
definition.zh: （数值或状态）快速下滑、骤降（常用于价格、销量、信心或表现）。

examples.en: Stock prices are slumping this week.
examples.zh: 本周股价在下跌。

examples.en: After the scandal, public support was slumping.
examples.zh: 丑闻之后，公众支持度迅速下滑。

extraExplanation: “slump”既可指“身体塌着坐/站”的姿态，也常用于经济与数据语境，表示“突然下滑”。在写作中，描述人物情绪时用“slumping”很形象：不直接说“他很沮丧”，而用动作让读者感受到疲惫或失落。

summary.en: “Slums” means very poor, overcrowded urban areas with bad housing conditions.
summary.zh: “slums”指城市中贫困、拥挤、居住条件差的区域（贫民窟/棚户区）。

definition.en: a very poor and crowded area of a city, where housing is in bad condition and services may be limited
definition.zh: （城市中）贫民窟；棚户区（通常拥挤、贫困、居住条件差、公共服务不足）

examples.en: Many families live in slums on the edge of the city.
examples.zh: 许多家庭住在城市边缘的贫民窟里。

examples.en: The charity provides clean water and medical care in the slums.
examples.zh: 这个慈善机构在贫民窟提供清洁饮水和医疗服务。

examples.en: He grew up in the slums but worked hard to change his life.
examples.zh: 他在贫民窟长大，但努力改变了自己的人生。

extraExplanation: “slum”常带有强烈的社会问题含义（贫困、不平等、住房与公共卫生条件差）。在更中性或正式的语境中，有时会用“informal settlements（非正规住区）”“low-income neighborhoods（低收入社区）”“underserved communities（资源不足社区）”等表达，但这些词的侧重点不同：并不总是等同于“slums”。
在英语文学与新闻写作中，“the slums”常用来概括城市贫困地带（例如“the slums of London”），但在现实交流中谈及具体社区时，注意避免把人群简单标签化，可多用强调“people living in…”的表达。

summary.en: A “slur” can mean an offensive insult (especially about identity), unclear speech (“slur your words”), or a musical curved line connecting notes; as a verb it can also mean to smear someone’s reputation.
summary.zh: “slur”可指侮辱性辱骂用语（尤其针对身份）、说话含糊不清（口齿不清），也可指乐谱中的连音线；作动词还可表示诋毁名誉。

definition.en: an offensive word or phrase used to insult a person or group (often targeting identity such as race, nationality, gender, etc.)
definition.zh: （尤指针对身份特征如种族、国籍、性别等的）侮辱性称呼；辱骂用语

examples.en: Using racial slurs is hateful and unacceptable.
examples.zh: 使用种族辱骂用语是充满仇恨且不可接受的。

examples.en: He was fired after he shouted a slur at a customer.
examples.zh: 他对顾客喊出侮辱性称呼后被解雇了。
